Name: JAN SHIKSHAN SANSTHAN BANDA UP
Major_Activities1: The JSS has been active in Banda District for last fifteen years. The major achievement being it has successfully established its credibility and gencunily in the targeted group. Banda has always been a remote and under developed district where the girls specially from our targeted class were not even allowed to come out of home, but to this scheme the girls have lapped up in a big way, ninety percent of our beneficiaries being girls. Now they appear to be more confidence of their needs and capabilities. N.P.E.G.E.L.has been providing skill development training to schools and colleges under Basic Shiksha Parishad. Here clear preference has been given to the candidates trained by JSS Banda to impart the training on the basis of their reputation. An information stall (Centre) was organized at Girwan under Bharat Nirman Jan Suchana programme. Similarly an information stall (Centre) was organized at Govt Inter College Srinagar Mahoba in coordination with P.I.P Kanpur. A certificate to the effect of commendable work and the third Prize and a Shield was given to JSS Banda. In the programme for making Sansad Adarsh Gram Katra Kalinjar 100 percent literate, the JSS Banda and Rajya Sansadhan Kendra LKO organized poppet show, wall painting activities, poster and Board display and contributed to it success at Pipramaaf Mahoba and Katra Kalinjar. The Nav Sakshars were distributed Stationery items by JSS Banda & were duly encouraged under directions of Govt of India. For their commendable contribution Shri, Aslam & Smt. Madhu our Prerak were awarded with Shield & Certificate of Merrit by Rajya Sansadhan Kendra & Vaikalpik Shiksha Nideshalay Lucknow. Ammong our Trainees Mrs. Arti Singh Marka Village was provided with a Loan of Rs. 1 Lac by Khadi Gramodyog Board to establish a Unit. Mrs. Usha Khare was helped in securing similar Loan with our efforts to establish a unit. Both of them are reportedly earning to the tune of Rs. 5000/= a growth & regularly paying back their loan. Mr. Kashi Prasad with our efforts secured a loan of Rs. 50,000/= from Allahabad Bank under Pradhan Manti Mudra rin Yojna be also successfully repaying his loan. JSS organized an activity under Prime Minister Swachhata Pakhwada at Saraswati Balika Vidhya Mandir Inter College Ken Path. Essays & debates were organized on the subject Swachha Bharat, Green Bharat and Environment around 20 Students participated. They were duly awarded and refreshment was arranged.

Name: DISHA ACADEMY
Major_Activities1: Brief history of the Institute: Palli Sree Ram Memorial Society is a Training & Educational Society for mainly needy students. We are working to import and development social awareness among the less educated youth by organizing awareness camps from time to time .Society founded in Feb 2013 with it has its headquarters located at Kolkata, West Bengal, India. The Society has been set up by some successful educationalists of India with a purpose to make it one of the most unique Training and Education Facilitator in India. The objective has been to provide youths with quality education and equipping them with unique skills to enable them to give themselves a head start in the job market mainly. At the same time, help industry to deliver internationally competitive performance by having access to locally available, internationally benchmarked, skilled manpower trained in line with their requirements. Palli Sree Memorial Society is the partner of Disha Academy .Where Disha Academy is an empanelled training organization by PBSSD. Disha Academy is taking care of vocational training part of Palli Sree Memorial Society. Achievements Of Palli Sree Ram Memorial Society Palli Sree Memorial Society is working as a partner of Disha Academy, Disha Academy is enlisted at Paschim Banga Society For Skill Development At Palli Sree Ram Memorial Society our approach to vocational training and women empowerment is path breaking. We do not provide students what they need, instead our approach has been to identify market requirement and structure our curriculum to transfer those skills to our students. For us Vocational training is incomplete without jobs. Hence every focus in our vocational training initiative is JOBS. At the name of Disha Academy(Palli Sree Memorial Society ) have given training in 18 Govt Schools and Colleges and trained almost 1200 Students and among them 854 students have already placed in different Companies. We have taken workshop for Visva Bharati Faculties for written and Verbal Communication We have a unique process wherein we have identified the KRAs of the work that a 1 year experienced resource would do on finding a good job. These KRAs(Key Result Area) have been designed in content form and students are trained to perform these activities in a LIVE WORKING ENVIRONMENT projects Student is also prepared for first hour productivity and interview readiness. This is a high demand career program. We are organizing different awareness camps for women empowerment, distribution of cloth and food to the distress women. Palli Sree Memorial Society is identifying society needs and try to work on that. Ongoing projects We are running two projects at the moment in the name of Disha Academy, First one is from West Bengal Scheduled caste and schedule tribe & Finance and Corporation, we are providing tailoring and master tailoring MES Course to 100 SC & ST youth. Second one is from Social Directorate of women and child welfare west bengal, we are training and preparing 42 women inmates in Bedside assistant MES course at Vidya Sagar Balika Bhavan, Paschim Medinipur.

Trainings have been conducted with support from the Department of Chemicals & Petrochemicals, Government of India.

Name: Adarsh Mook Badhir Vidyalaya
Major_Activities1: Adarash Mook Badhir Vidyalaya Lakhimpur Kheri (U P) is established July 1976 in Distt. Kheri. This institute was founded by Sri Ram Dularey Verma for the better education and to make deaf mutes useful citizen and self reliant. This institute is only one such type of nearby five Distt – Piliphit , Shahjehapur , Hardoi, Sitapur, Bahraich. The school imparts free education all section of society without any discrimination. Handclapped children are takes in a active part in all activities like indoor and outdoor games. National festivals 15 August, 26 January, 2 October and Disabled day 3 December in every year celebrated. School building is own. The land of building was donated by distt. Majistrate Sri. Indu Kumar Pandey from willoughy memorial trust. Funds of the building is received from Netherlands with the help of Indu Rama Srivastav and some rooms are constricted by M P Funds Sri Ravi Prakash Verma and M L A Funds Sri. Dhirendra Bahadur Singh , Dr. Kaushal Kishor and Ram Gopal Verma. The school is aided from Social justice and empowerment (disability Deptt). Govt. of India. Now the school is running smoothly. Parents are satisfied school activities and imparting education to the deaf and dumb children.

Name: pragathi charities
Major_Activities1: MAJOR ACTIVITIES/ ACHIEVEMENTS Pragathi Charities has taken up challenging measures for running Special Schools for multiple disabled to cater the education needs of the Disabled Community under the provocation of the Government in Nellore District, Pragathi Charities has taken up the following programmes for the benefits of the disabled in Nellore District of Andhra Pradesh state. 1) SPECIAL SCHOOL FOR MENTALLY RETARDED, WOOD COMPLEX, NELLORE : This school has grown up in several ways to meet the increasing case load and developed as a full-fledged school, Out of 150 beneficiaries 90 are hostlers the remaining 30 children are day scholars. The organization has recruited 27 members of staff as per staff pattern and guidelines from by Ministry of Social Justice, GOI during 2013-14. 2) SPECIAL SCHOOL FOR HEARING HANDICAPPED, NELLORE : There are 80 students in the school out of which 46 are Hostlers the remaining 26 children are day scholars. The organization has recruited 20 members of staff as per staff pattern and guidelines from by Ministry of Social Justice, GOI during 2013-14. RECOGNITION:- This organization has been registered under PWD act vide 1. Certificates of Recognition (No 2 of 2003) up to 18.08.2017. 2. Certificate of form B grant of Recognition (No 2 of 2003) up to 30.9.2015 by the Asst. Director welfare disabled and Sr. Citizens, SPSR, Nellore Dist. Dated 11.10.2012. 3. This Special School has been recognized by the State Government from 2003-04 from Ist to VIIth Class vide Rc.No.6226/A7/2009 dated 09-11-2009 of the District Educational Officer (FAC), Nellore and renewed the recognition vide DEO’s RC NO.9470/B1/2012 dt. 06-07-2013. We are getting 100% results both in VII and X Classes every year. We are sending VIII to Xth Class students for the Examinations every year as Private candidates. Distribution of free Books: the Distinct Educational Officer Nellore, has supplied free N.T. Books to all the hearing unimpaired children’s from 1st to 10th Class- every year 3) TRAINING PROGRAMMES (Human Resource Developments) :- 1) Special B. Ed. ( MR) :- The another achievement under Man Power development is that we have started “College of Special Education B. Ed. – Mental Retardation” from 2007-08 with 25 No. of students which is permitted by the RCI, New Delhi and affiliated by Sri Venkateswara University – Tirupati and Vikram Simhapuri University Nellore. A Total 144 candidates are appeared for the Spl. B.Ed(MR) Course and passed 136 candidates successfully as detailed here under from 2007-08 to 2014-15. 95% candidates who passed Spl. B.Ed (MR) have got employment in Rajiv Vidya Mission in various Districts in the state of Andhra Pradesh and Maharashtra. 2) D.C.B.R. Course :- We have started Diploma in Community Based Rehabilitation Course during 2006-07 with 20 No’s. But now it is discontinued. 3) Special D.Ed ( MR) Course: This course started in August 2015 with the permission of Rehabilitation Council of India, New Delhi and affiliated to NIEPMD, Chennai. 25 Candidates appeared for the Examination in the month of June’2016 and waiting for Results. 4) Special D.Ed ( HI) Course: This course started in August 2016 with the permission of Rehabilitation Council of India, New Delhi and affiliated to AYJNIHH, Mumbai. 21 Candidates are admitted, during the academic year 2016-17.. 3) District Disabled Rehabilitation Resource Centre :- The Consulate general of JAPAN (Chennai) has caused Inspection of this Project during 2007 – 08 and sanctioned grant to the Project in 2009 – 10. We have started this District Disabled Rehabilitation Resource Centre (D.D.R.R.C.) with the support of JAPAN Consulate with an estimate of Rs.44 Lakhs for constructing 12 Rooms at Ambapuram Village, Nellore Mandal. The Consulate General of Japan, G.G.P. Unit, Chennai has released US Dollars 97,087 worth Rs.44 Lakhs and the Construction of these DRRC building has completed and inaugurated on 27.3.2013 by Masanori Nakano, consul – consulate general of Japan at Chennai. Vocational trainings like candle Making, chalk piece Making, Tailoring, computer Education training etc. are started to the disabled.

Name: SPECTRA Organisation
Major_Activities1: 1. To arrange modern education and training for all round development of students & adults rural education, nationalism, social integration, besides this inculcation in them intellectual cultural and heritage values and motivating them to follow them. 2. To help in solving the problems of development of industries, self dependence and increasing population, un employment imparting training in the field of technology and raising avenues for self employment. 3. Development of scientific knowledge, technical expertise, modern & hereditary artistic items for village handicaps and weaker sections of the society along with their social intellectual, and rules for forestry development etc. 4. Keeping in very the human service as basis for the development betterment of backward & poor, arrange living accommodation with clean environment self employment, medical & health services and other civil amenities work for awareness about forest, women equality children protection and against exploitation. 5. To carry out all those activities for the development of society and promotion of objects of the society . 6. Keeping in view the local and national needs promoting the education, through various languages literature, science, arts technology health and others, present and others, present and future educational systems and opening, schools, collages Training. Institution, Hostels & hospitals, orphanage with special attention of women and child development. 7. Protection of child right, safety health and education. Combating exploitation of child labour, slavery, sale of child sexual abuse, domestic violence. Under domestic and inter national laws and work for their education, training and rehabilitation Health The goal of the SPECTRA As health programme is to achieve sustainable improvements in health status among vulnerable groups, especially the geographically remote, women of childbearing age and children under five. Health is more then health care, while the SPECTRA work the strengthen health systems and services, it also promotes initiatives that offer people the knowledge and skills to avoid illness. These measures include educating women and girls and enabling families to adopt appropriate hygiene practices. In addition, the SPECTRA supports testing and implementation of income-generating strategies that allow households and communities to acquire better nutrition and health status. Increased income enables communities to improve nutritional status, particularly that of women and children, and to build and maintain water and sanitation systems. Education  A major goal of the SPECTRA is to improve the quality of basic education. Four objectives set the wider agenda: ensuring better early caring and learning environments for young children; increasing access to education; keeping children in school longer; and raising levels of academic achievement. In common with other donor agencies, the SPECTRA intend those girls, the very poor, and geographically remote populations should receive special attention. Of the may factors, that influences the quality of basis education. SPECTRA education portfolio is distinctive in one other respect. It interprets’ basis education’ as the continuation of learning which stretches from birth to adolescence. In developing countries, the young children and the family portfolio is experimenting in both rural and urban settings with various community-based approaches that enhance early childcare and education opportunities, A common concern across most of these projects is the quality of experience received as a child moves from home to early childhood development settings to primary school. Rural Development The SPECTRA is committed to reducing rural poverty, particularly in resource-poor, degraded or remote environments. It concentrates on a small number of programms of significant sale. The model of participatory rural development it has pioneered combines a set of common development principles with the flexibility to respond to specific contexts and needs. Programmes typically link elements such as rural savings and credit, natural resource management, productive infrastructure development, increased agricultural productivity and human skill development with a central concern for community-level participation and decision-making. The ultimate goal is to enable community members to make informed choices from a range of appropriate options for sustainable and equitable development. A central strategy has been to crate or strengthen an institutional structure at the village level through which people can determine priority needs decide how best to manage common resources in the interests of the community as a whole. Whether, broad-based or task-specific, these village organizations’ also serve to represent the community to the government and two other development partners, including NGOs and the private sector. Social capital built at the local level provides a supportive environment for enlarging the economic assets of a community and for harnessing individual self-interest to generate income growth in a equitable and sustainable manner. Assets are typically built through community management of neutral resources-water storage, irrigation infrastructure, soil conservation or forestry – or the construction of basic economic infrastructure, such as rural roads or agricultural storage facilities. Income growth is promoted by increasing agricultural productivity through improved farming methods, input supply, marketing, land development and management reform or by increasing off-farm income and supporting enterprise development. Local capital is mobilized by promoting savings and development financial services to enable broad access to credit on a sustainable basis. Training programme support the effectiveness and sustainability of the village-level institutions by providing the management and technical skills needed to plan, implement and maintain local development activities. The SPECTRA is committed to building the knowledge base in rural development through learning, analyzing and disseminating lessons learners from field experience. Community Participation The benefits of community participation in development programme have been richly demonstrated. Local people can acquire the organized capacity to define and meet common needs on a sustainable basis. Each year the range of problems poor communities’ address through participatory efforts grows – as does the SPECTRAs understanding of what is needed to champion local initiative. Full participation comes most quickly when there are immediate, tangible benefits from community action. Projects that bring economic rewards, for instance, move forward faster than those aimed solely at preventing health problems. As community organizations created for economic benefit mature, however, they gain the confidence and vision to address longer-term social needs successfully. The potential of these groups is vast. Support organizations need to listen carefully. Community groups want to be heard, to be offered choices, to have central roles in project management and a genuine stake in the outcome. As the Foundation monitors community initiatives in different cultural and geographical settings, it is learning what combinations of these factors bring maximum social and economic benefits over time. It is also learning the limits to the effectiveness of community participation, Experience shows, for example, that small enterprises are beat run by individuals or partners rather than community organizations. Gender and Development The SPECTRAs is committed to highlighting the essential role of women in the development process and to facilitating their participation. Research and experience have shown that considering gender considerations in planning economic and social interventions greatly increases the probability of their success. In most countries and communities, gender determines both domestic and productive roles. Women generally have responsibilities for both, but their ability to contribute to society is constrained by social, cultural and political traditions. Compared to men, they tend to be less educated, more limited in their options and paid less. Yet women manage households, raise children, pass knowledge to the next generation, lend livestock, grew, and process crops and often run businesses to supplement family income. Families and communities benefit exponentially when women reap greater rewards for their own efforts and labor. Once sustenance needs are covered, women quickly address the health and education needs of other generations. To raise the competence and confidence of women – and, correspondingly, to open the thinking of men-is a long term commitment of the SPECTRAs. In addition to supporting research and action aimed at making women’s participation a reality, the SPECTRAs support women with village credit schemes, training in forestry, masonry , crop and livestock management accounting and marketing. It encourages education and careers for women. It looks for ways to engage with men around the attitudinal and structural changes that flow from programmesthat benefit women. The Environment In resource-poor areas, people and the environment are often trapped together in a downward spiral. Penury of natural resources forces the less privileged to consume the few resources available to them. The result is deeper poverty deplaned soils, deforested hills, polluted water, disease, and despair. The Spectra’s rural development programms combine local organization, appropriate technology, and investment in efforts to reverse this destructive course. Health, education and capacity development programmes also help to raise awareness of environmental issues and encourage people to manage to change in the best interests of the community. The environment includes natural, built and cultural factors that cut across virtually all development programmes. Each profoundly, affects the human conditions, and all are interrelated, Environmental problems are complex and often extremely difficult to slove. Even the smallest steps in the right direction have positive implications for rich and poor alike. Child Labourers Our main objects for child labourers  To focus public attention and pressure the government to evolve and implement effective policies and programmes, which would incline having both agricultural and domestic labour declared as hazardous.  To highlight sectarian violations against child labours, especially the girl child labourers.  To impress upon the public the hazards faced by domestic girl child labourers the exploitative work environment with long hours of work, low rewards, and a relatively high level of physical and even sexual abuse.  To demand for the eradication of child labour in general.

Name: Special Olympics Bharat
Major_Activities1: Special Olympics Bharat is a National Sports Federation for Development of Sports for the Intellectually Disabled, recognized by the Ministry of Sports & Youth Affairs, Government of India and the internationally accredited program of Special Olympics Inc, USA Special Olympics Bharat was registered with the Indian Trusts Act 1882 in 2001 and recognized by the Government of India as a National Sports Federation 2006 in the Priority Category for the development of Sports for Persons with Intellectual Disabilities. It has been designated as the Nodal Agency in 2010 by the Government for conduct of sports for all disabilities on account of its national presence; outreach and experience. SO Bharat sports program reaches to all schools in rural areas through the Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan Scheme. Special Olympics Bharat works across all States and Union Territories in India covering 679 districts, having registered 12,43, 246 Athletes and 1,19,900 Coaches in the year 2015 Special Olympics World Games are held every two years alternating between Summer Games and Winter Games across different global locations. Our Athletes have brought laurels to the country with their successful participation at the World Games since 1987. 885 Athletes have participated in the Special Olympics World Games so far, bringing back a rich haul of 322 Gold, 343 Silver and 397 Bronze Medals reaching a cumulative figure of 1062 Medals. The Central Government institutionalized Cash Awards for Medallists in January 2015 to the tune of Rs. 5 Lakhs, 3 Lakhs and 1 Lakh for winners of Gold, Silver and Bronze respectively. The Walt Disney Company, ESPN and Special Olympics entered into a collaboration to leverage the power of sports to promote an environment of social inclusion and acceptance, by uniting people with and without intellectual disabilities through the Special Olympics Unified Sports Program. Unified Sports activities in India assumed a position of central importance through this partnership, making it a part of Strategic Growth. By December 2015 India has been successful in combining 1, 54,464 Athletes with 1, 70,939 Unified Partners. Supported by TATA Trust, ‘Rehabilitation Program for persons with disabilities using sports and building communities as instruments of change’, a 3-year pilot study in Ranchi and Namkum was launched in July 2013. The project completed successfully in June 2016 covering 3000 Athletes, creating a platform for presenting latent abilities from the remote interiors of the State. Few Athletes and Coaches from this program have reached National level trainings and competitions with 2-3 also being strong contenders to participate in the upcoming Special Olympics World Games Special Olympics and Tottenham Hotspur Foundation (THF) are delivering an International Disability project that will improve the quality of coaching in India for people with intellectual disabilities, leading to a greater talent pool across the country. THF Coaches travelled to India, training 200 Coaches across 4 Camps. The program progressed to further train more Coaches and Athletes. SO Bharat was successful in training 2655 Coaches and 39,825 Athletes.

Monovikas Puraskar Award was also haned to this organization in 2014. 4. In the field of Special Olympic, Bharat also some students from our organization got gold and silver award. 5. Name: BHARATESH EDUCATION TRUST
Major_Activities1: Bharatesh Education Trust was started in 1962 by a bunch of passionate young entrepreneurs who wanted to bring about a meaningful change in the society by means of education. Today the trust encompasses over 20 educational institutions, a rural hospital to cater to the needs of the rural poor, reaching out to the underprivileged through the community polytechnic and strengthening eager hands through its skill development activities. The span of our activities spreads from KG to PG, across three beautiful and buzzing campuses in and around Belagavi city. It has 500 staff members on the roll of the institution and over 8000 students avail quality education imparted at its institutions The trust provides scholarship aid to minority, meritorious, financially weak and socially backward class students of this area. Minority scheme benefits are also availed by the qualifying students. Dengue Check up and preventive camp are conducted as a Community Development program by Bharatesh Homeopathic Hospital Belagavi. Over 45500 people were benefited by the camp. Blood donation camps in villages and Primary Health Centre are also a part of the trust’s contribution to the society Through the Department of District Health & Family Welfare Office Physical Disability Assessment Camp was conducted and disability certificates were issued on the spot so that the beneficiaries could get the medical appeases. The community development program through polytechnic have trained over 5000 students in rural area and empowered on various entrepreneurial skills such as tailoring, toy making, etc. Trust also empowers women and conducts Women Empowerment Program from time to time. Most of the above programs are free of cost and inclined towards the benefit of the society at large. The trust has 3 Institutions accredited by NAAC National Assessment and Accreditation Council and 1 accredited by NBA. Faculties and management members of the trust have bagged awards at state and national level. All the employees are covered under PF, Gratuity and ESI. The trust is covered under 80G and 35AC under the Income Tax Act

Name: Shri Jal Jivan Jyot Stree Sahayak Vividh Utpadak Sahakari Mandli Ltd
Major_Activities1: Our society is dedicated towards the Artisans of the country. The prime requirement of the rural Artisans is to unite and form a business oriented group. That entails them to move ahead, negotiate and chalk out future plan on their own terms. In old days, formation of such guilds was very normal and allowed our Artisan and their art to grow. However with passage of time, the culture of the guild disappeared from our country, rendering the Artisans alone and helpless. This is where our society is contributing. We organize the Artisans in to community based enterprises like SHG or COOPs etc. Thus we make them in to a group of active entrepreneurs and primary stakeholders in the process of development. Our activity can be further summarized as under –1) Regularly organize the training programs for our artisans. Educate them in to new technics, new designs and the latest market trend. The purpose is to bring them at par with the market-trend. We also invite the faculties from various fields , many a times with active support from the govt bodies, so that our artisans can interact freely. 2) We fully understand that, focusing only on the commercial part is not sufficient. Hence ,we also consider the social and familial structure of our villages. Thus we specially organize the training modules for our women artisans. Not only we cover the technical issues, but we specifically cover the issues related to literacy & girl child, sanitation, child upbringing and introducing the basics of finance/banking. 3) Supporting our artisans to market their products is the most crucial part of our entire activity. If our trained Artisans are not able to find a customer, then the whole purpose of the activity is defeated. We organize the marketing events for our artisans on national level. Thus we bridge the gap between our artisans and the potential customer. These events are well planned and artisans are informed in advance about schedule. We strive to have maximum participation. Thus our society is in an active supportive role, in every stage of development. From initial training up to marketing, we take care of our artisans at every step. Achievement organised training program trained 320 artisans organised workshop program trained 300 artisans organised gandhi shilp bazar at ahmedabad and craft bazar at vadodara during the year 2011-12, 2012-13 ,2013-14 for marketing platform to artisans under DCH scheme
issues_working_db: Women's Development & Empowerment,
nr_add: GF-8, Ivory Tarrace, Alkapuri,Vadodara, Gujarat,India (390007)

Name: Space Shikshan Samiti
Major_Activities1: Space Shikshan Samiti is a social development organization formed by likeminded people engaged in the social development sector. The organization has been established with an aim to help and supports the underprivileged and not so exposes rural people to empower them and bring into justice, equity, freedom, and solidarity so as to demands their rights. The organization has focus on various aspects to promote Rural education, vocational training, Energy security and rural electrification, EcoTourism, Health, Human rights, environment, age care and other development work of rural communities. Our Organization is one established name in Skill Development / Vocational Training in the industrial belt of eastern India dominated by economically poor, primarily tribal population. High quality teaching, personal attention on personality development, fully valid and valuable certifications and assured placement at course end at lowest possible fess is hall-mark of our delivery system. Our efforts have yielded into skill-growth and employment in organized sector for good number of youths mainly from underprivileged category. Vision To bring up a new generation of children, young women youthfully equipped with education potential to generate employment with quality and construction imagination. Our organization realizes that in all development process, women’s participation must be ensured and community involvement and active participation is essential for sustainability of the programmes and balanced development. Strategy The strategic planning for the organization is being done by the governing member. However, much earlier the organization has registered; the group has been started working with the people by visiting to the community, rural areas interacting with the people to learn more about problems exist and its cause and effect.

Name: BABA BAIDYANATH BALIKA MOOK BADHIR VIDYALAYA
Major_Activities1:  From the very year 1986 onward this institution has shouldered the responsibility of ‘Beti Bachao, Beti Parahao’ specially for deaf and dumb, physically handicapped girls who have become a serious burden for their parents. As a matter of fact such mega step on his part is highly commendable and memorable to make society better. Besides, it has been the prime concern of this institution to make society clean and healthy.  This institution is a residential school where pious work is going on since 26 January 1986 by way of imparting education, food, cloth, medical facility, technical and vocational training to poor deaf-dumb (hearing handicapped ) girls free of cost. For their mental health Yoga training is also imparted to them.  This institution has activated himself tremendously in pulse-polio Programme under the banner of the Govt. of India and thus he has helped the infants from zero to five years particularly in the backward regions of Munger Districty.  This institution has come on forefront by bagging the “FIRST PRISE” 2008 by the govt. of Bihar on the historic birth centenary of Baba Sahab Dr. Bhim Rao Ambedhkar in the wake of performing important and good deeds towards the welfare of the neglected hearing handicapped, physically handicapped women and children of the society and also got many national and various social organization awards and certificates for it’s tremendously work.  Significantly to mention, more than thousands deaf-dumb, physically handicapped women and girls and street children irrespective of caste and creed contained in this class in various districts of Bihar and Jharkhand have been tremendously benefitted and there is no full stop in his work and in future more and more are likely to register. Unquestionably this institution is a boon to the ailing humanity.

Name: Shram Sadhana Amravati
Major_Activities1: Krishi Vigyan Kendra, Durgapur, Dist. Amravati has been established in July,1995 with the responsibilities to bring forth agricultural vis-a vis rural development in the area through its mandated activities on training, front line demonstrations and on farm testing/adaptive trials. Ever since it became functional in the year 1996, it has made several innovative interventions in the agricultural development process of the district. Shram Sadhana, Amravati being a pioneer voluntary organization in the field of women and child development and water conservation work, the major focus was to develop the villages facing acute shortage of irrigation water to fulfill the minimum requirements of the farmers. Keeping this aspect in view, KVK applied its efforts to develop rain water harvesting models. KVK has introduced various water conservation models such as small farm ponds, Gabbian structures, Wanrai bandhara, and low cost rain water harvesting structures benefitting 158 farmers from Isambri village. The model developed by KVK as part of demonstrating rain water harvesting technologies has become a living example and it is replicated by State Department of Agriculture as “Isambri Model” after the name of the village where 441 TCM rain water was harvested by using all water conservation structures. Development of farming system module for rainfed farmers, sustainable dry land agriculture, in-situ soil and water conservation practices to increase productivity in rainfed conditions, up-gradation of local goat by Usmanabadi buck are only few of the numerous contributions made by the kendra within a short span of time. KVK focused its directions towards Integrated Pest Management (IPM) in cotton and chickpea with the concept of block demonstrations. The villages namely Kohala Jateshwar, Nimbhora, Pala, Kajana, Khartalegaon, Sawarkhed, Kumagarh, Lehgaon, etc. are developed as IPM villages. This technology is being practiced on more than 500 ha of area in these villages and diffusion of technology is observed in every village of the district. The average cost of cultivation of IPM farmer reduced to ` 6300 per acre as compared to ` 7900 per acre before IPM with 28 per cent increase in productivity. Application of chemical pesticide sprays have been reduced to 2 to 3 as compared to 8 to 10 before IPM. More than 45 per cent increase in net income is observed in IPM trained farmers. Now, the KVK is identified as a resource centre for IPM technology particularly in cotton, chickpea, soybean and Nagpur Mandarin. Krishi Vigyan Kendra has also established a Model Farm to disseminate and demonstrate the agro techniques suitable to the local farming community in the district for sustainable development. This model farm, equipped with modern irrigation system has important horticultural crops like guava, sweet Nagpur Mandarin, Nagpur Mandarin, sapota, custard apple and mango developed on 4 ha area to cater to the need of farmers in the district. Out of the total land 6 ha is utilized for crop production purpose like crop cafeteria, seed production, technology demonstrations, farm trials, etc. Fodder crops are cultivated on 1 ha area and teak is planted on 0.80 ha land. The instructional farm also acts as a technology assessment centre before their transfer to the farmers of the operational area. The training cum demonstration units like nursery, fruit and vegetable processing, vermicomposting, bio-agents and biopesticide production, mushroom cultivation, spawn production, soybean processing, Information and communication technology with video conferencing facility and animal production are established to meet the training need of farmers and in order to supply the required quality material to them. The facilities for Soil and Water testing, Phyto diagnostic, Post Harvest Technology Laboratory and an Agricultural Technology Information Centre is available with the KVK. Facility for Nagpur Mandarin rootstock DNA testing is unique contribution of the KVK developed for Nagpur Mandarin growing farmers of the area. As a Village Agriculture Knowledge Hub, KVK adopted 7 villages in Amravati district to facilitate the farmers about market information, weather information, disease information at the village level. The KVK acts as a vocational training centre to work at the grass root level for imparting need-based training and skills in the field of agriculture and rural development. KVK has offered trainings to 22430 participants by conducting 787 training programmes for its cliental with the help of its multidisciplinary team. 288 on farm trials are conducted for assessment and refinement of the recent agricultural technologies. Front line demonstrations are conducted on 1166 ha area covering 2232 farmers and in animal science 144 animals covering 144 farmers, in agriculture engineering frontline demonstrations conducted on farm implements on 143 ha area covering 196 farmers. With extension activities like Field days, Exhibitions, Kisan Mela, Diagnostic visits, Advisory services, Video Conferencing etc. KVK covered 2,17,947 farmers of the area. Helpline services and mobile messaging services are started by the KVK benefitting 9400 farmers. In order to improve the socio-economic situation of the women in agriculture and for drudgery reduction 345 women self help groups are formed. KVK has formed 142 farmers club at village level to identify and communicate their problems related to agriculture and allied activities. KVK frequently organizes meetings for interaction between scientists and farmers. This has led to increased productivity and overall output of the village and has made a concrete difference to the standard of living of the villagers. The growth of this KVK has been steady and relatively faster because, besides the support of the ICAR, it has financial as well as administrative linkages and support of the Govt. KVK is fully functional in its operational area with record achievements and has bagged award of excellence for best work done under ATMA project. Since inception the KVK has performed as lighthouse for farming community of the district and gained faith of the rural population and lot of reliability and trust of the farmers.

Name: THAKUR HARI PRASAD INSTITUTE OF RESEARCH AND REHABILITATION FOR THE MENTALLY HANDICAPPED
Major_Activities1: Thakur Hari Prasad Institute of Research and Rehabilitation for the Mentally Handicapped was founded by (late) Dr. Thakur V. Hari Prasad on16/09/1968. THPI is a professionally managed premier voluntary organisation grown over 48 years on the firm foundation of a multidisciplinary approach to rehabilitation of persons with mental handicap since inception. Its accomplishments encompass many unprecedented initiatives, many sojourns into hitherto untread areas of rehabilitation services. Its philosophy and vision are coherent with its mission and implementation modes. It aims at promoting the quality of life of persons with mental handicap and associated disabilities through a holistic multidisciplinary qualitative service-delivery. The Institute has been accorded special consultative status by United Nations. THPI is recipient of National and International Awards from the President of India & RCI Hong Kong Foundation International and many other awards in recognition of its outstanding performance in the field of Handicapped Welfare. It is the only institute honoured with UGC award. Situated on a campus of five acres with total barrier free environment. Members comprising of Rehabilitation Professionals, Personnel, CBR workers and Administrative staff are involved in the service delivery. The Rehabilitation Professionals include Neuro-paediatricians, Psychiatrists, Clinical Psychologists, Special Educators, Speech Pathologists & Audiologists, Physio Therapists, Occupational Therapists and Medical& Psychiatric Social workers for rehabilitation of Persons with Mental Handicap. It also offers augmentative interventions to supplement therapeutic interventions through Dance therapy, Music therapy, Yoga therapy, Hydro therapy, Multi Media, Games & Sports & Performing arts etc. Training of human resource at different levels, research, advocacy, policy development are some of the other major pursuits of the organisation. Involved in various avenues of operation individually and also in collaboration with many national and international voluntary agencies and government machinery. Its initiatives are unprecedented and cost effective. Developed innovative viable models that have emerged as a result of THPI’s explorations have implications for national level replication. The horizons of the large spectrum of THPI’s pursuits encompass concern for:  Protection of rights of persons with mental handicap and other disabilities in general,  Empowerment of persons with disabilities and their families through access to services access to information and promotion of their participation.  Enhancing the dignity of persons with disabilities through valued approaches and strategies of public education, awareness creation and community participation. Believer of convergence of services and utilizing available manpower and infrastructure resources for mainstreaming the rehabilitation process ranging from prevention of disabilities, early detection, early intervention, education, training, employment and integration into the community. The Service users of THPI belong to all strata of society in Tribal, Rural & Urban areas. The services offered by THPI include Institutional & Community based services. Human Resource Development Programmes : Rehabilitation Science is a growing discipline and there is dearth of Rehabilitation Professionals and Personnel to meet with the demand of Rehabilitation Services in India. Offers Certificate, Diploma, Graduate & Postgraduate level Training Programmes recognised by Rehabilitation Council of India, affiliated to Osmania University, Dr. B.R. Ambedkar Open University.

Name: Bombay Leprosy Project
Major_Activities1: Bombay Leprosy Project is a Charitable Organization engaged in leprosy relief work entirely through donations for the last four decades with the objective of providing free of cost clinical care and treatment services and thereby improving the quality of life of leprosy patients. Since 1976 the organization has been working relentlessly in implementing the policies of National Leprosy Eradication Programme and assisting the Government in its endeavor. Besides the activity related to diagnosis and treatment of patients, the Project has been carrying out Operational and Technical Research in the field of leprosy and has published over 350 scientific papers in Indian and International journals. The efforts of BLP have been highly recognized for its excellence in Leprosy research. Over the years though the prevalence of leprosy has come down with the implementation of Multi Drug Treatment (MDT) strategy, the problem of leprosy patients with clinical problems and disability caused by nerve damage still remains a huge challenge before the nation today. To address this issue, BLP has also been running Prevention and care of deformity (POD) care and services programme in the slums of Mumbai and also in the adjoining rural areas of Thane district to persons with leprosy related disability by providing them with aids and appliances like splints, finger loops, MCR footwear, dressing kits etc under the guidance of Physiotherapists and paramedical workers. BLP has also been practicing Integrated Rehabilitation programme to eliminate the stigma associated with the disease and fighting for human rights of persons afflicted with leprosy and other related diseases leading to disabilities for nearly four decades. Some of the achievements….. Undaunted by various odds, BLP has forged ahead in its mission and goals 1.Reached 1.95 million people of which 60% are from slums of Dharavi and other similar slums in G and H wards of Mumbai 2.35,000 patients have been cured with MDT. 3.Disabilities have been prevented in more than 3000 patients. 4.300 leprosy patients and physically challenged persons have been benefitted under this programme Our extensive studies and experience in Mumbai and adjoining rural areas from where patients travel quite a long distance to avail medical relief, clearly indicates the need for strengthening the Main Leprosy Referral Centre and satellite clinics to be equipped with experienced manpower and expertise with skills and necessary resources. These clinics are mainly integrated in the Govt Hospitals and municipal dispensaries and hospitals. We are therefore making every effort to further strengthen the existing Referral Centre and satellite clinics as this will help to improve the quality of services and also sustain clinical services to patients affected with leprosy. The Referral Centre is thronged by leprosy patients referred not only from Mumbai but also from adjoining districts of Thane, Raigad and other places of Maharashtra.

Name: Arunachala Animal Sanctuary and Rescue Shelter
Major_Activities1: Within a field of love, our Staff of 20 plus three full time veterinary doctors, using traditional and alternative medicines, lift suffering from over 5000 homeless dogs, thousands of owner dogs, and thousands of other animals. The core of our Work is demonstrative love. Our belief is that deep healing only takes place if a creature feels safe, cared for, and loved. When we first opened in 2007, there were over 5,000 homeless dogs and the stray population was out of control. With no small animal vet within 75 kms, no treatment facility, rabies, and widespread abuse, there was unbounded misery. There were perhaps 350 suffering and dying animals on the streets / mostly dogs and puppies, but monkeys, cows, and others, too. It was one of the worst situations I have seen. Today, it is very different. The most important thing that has happened is that the relationship between the homeless animals and the people amongst whom they live day in, day out has been transformed. And the lives of these creatures has been profoundly uplifted. One can experience the change by walking on the streets. Each year, street conditions get better and better, and Tiruvannamalai is perhaps the only municipality of size in the Nation where this has happened. The Animal Welfare Board of India in a public letter of endorsement has said, we are one of the very best in the Nation. We have 7 major programs. A sterilization/anti-rabies program. A clinic. Hospital facilities. Sanctuary, if an animal cannot make it on its own. And adoption program. 24/7 emergency rescue. Hospice. Since opening we have sterilized 6,296 dogs. Given 11,933 anti-rabies injections. Had 36,108 visits to our clinic. Given 102,548 in-patient treatments. Had 3,652 emergency rescues. Found good homes for 844 puppies/dogs. Treated 3,259 animals other than dogs. Our mission is to lift suffering from the Animal Realm. We will treat any animal in need. Large. Small. Wild. Domestic. Most of our services are free.

Major_Activities1: Srajan Shodh Sansthan Samitti Ujjain was established in the year 2007 with the prime object of Educational, Social Welfare of SC/ST/Minorities, Tribal and the other needy people of the society and especially to uplift child and women development. The society is registered under M.P Society Act 1973 under serial 44, Registration No 07/33/01/07253/07 dated 20-12-2007. The main motto of the society is to empower educational, Socio- economic, technical education skills of the needy people and make them socially, economically and educationally strong so that they will be able to live a main stream life. For achieving the objectives of the organizational strategy is to motivate minority people towards education, technical education and other integrated development through mobilizing natural and human resource. The society had got the work order to run a skill development program for the marginalized group we are working, for year 2015-16 and 2016-17 through order no. LOA/WA No: GAIL/CSR/3014/6300001429/01/15-16 and 16-17 of Rs 1,10,00,000/- The program is running successfully and had trained more than 500 students in different trades like computer software and hardware, Beauty Parlor ,Fashion Designing, Silai Kadai etc and more than 500 students are getting skilled currently. The society is going onward to start Block and Batik printing classes. We are aiming to work for adolescence girls through an awareness program based on Sanitary Napkin in Health and Hygiene program. The society is willing to work in rural sector for Bio-Diversity and watershed Program and is hopeful to be sanctioned. These projects are under procedure of sanctioning. Name: B V Patel Pharmaceutical Education and Research Development Centre
Major_Activities1: The B. V. Patel Pharmaceutical Education & Research Development (PERD) Centre was established in 1989 by the Gujarat Branch of the Indian Pharmaceutical Association with the help of Indian Pharmaceutical Companies and the Government of Gujarat, in the memory of late Shri. B. V. Patel, who was the first Drug Controller of Gujarat and truly considered as the father of drug legislation in India. PERD Centre is India’s first multidisciplinary research institute, dedicated to the pursuit of excellence in the pharmaceutical sciences. The focus of centre is on three aspects namely; Basic Research, Services to Industries and Continuing Education Program. PERD Centre brings together a diverse interdisciplinary team of experts in the basic science, chemistry, biotechnology, pharmacology, analytical, herbals and other areas of pharmaceuticals sciences. Industries Commissionerate, Government of Gujarat has recognized PERD Centre as Centre of Excellence (COE) for providing technical assistance to small & medium industries for quality control and quality assurance standards for drugs & drug formulations, and herbal drugs. PERD Centre has opened up for collaborations with industry both in India and abroad for developing formulations, synthesis of compound libraries in the therapeutic areas like Cancer, Inflammation, Diabetes and Infectious diseases, etc. Equipped with the latest and best R & D facilities, highly qualified scientific & technical personnel & regular education, training and developmental activities, PERD today is an internationally recognized research institute providing the Pharmaceutical Industry and Academia the opportunity and resources to undertake the latest in research and development in pharmaceutical sciences. The focus of research at PERD Centre is on drug discovery (synthetic, herbal, biotherapeutics), dug development, drug delivery, drug toxicity and efficacy. Our expertise is in the areas of – standardization of herbal drugs, impurity profiling of API, formulation development, mammalian cell culture studies, toxicity and pharmacokinetic studies in animals. Over the past few years, PERD Centre has produced a number of publications in peer-reviewed journals, national and international patents and awards thereby recognizing the potential and capabilities of the institute and its faculties. The Centre also has a distinction of getting research grants both from State and Central Government.

Name: C V S Krishnamurthy Teja Charities
Major_Activities1: C.V.S Krishnamurthy teja Charities is a non profitable organization registered in the year 1997 under the Act of 1882 at tirupati. The objectives of trust are: 1) To establish aid and maintain education at all stages for the promotion of Dental, Paramedical, engineering, Law, commerce and Sciences for diffusion of useful knowledge in Andhra Pradesh . 2) To give food, water and medical relief to the poor and ols age pensions. 3) To promote and maintain Research for and advancement of scientific and technical knowledge trust established Research cell. 4) To pay school and college fees, provide clothing, books to the needy students and to give scholarships to enable poor boys and girls irrespective of caste , to pursue their education and provided meritorious awards and rewards for outstanding personalities. 5) To uplift the knowledge of in rural area by conducting social and economic welfare programs. 6) To arrange, organize and patronize by providing finance for marriage of poorer section community and also arrange for funeral and obsequies for orphan. 7) To organize camps for handicapped persons and assists them in providing artificial limbs and finance for their education, employment and other activities. 8) To construct in the name of trust , special awards for best teachers for their outstanding performance in their respective schools, doctors for their proper medicare for poorer sections. 9) To adopt a panchayat, village or any rural area for maintenance of education, medical aid or uplift of poor and needy. 10) To meet the present day technologies trust has organized workshops on computer fundamentals and internet. 11) To bring joy and harmony in the families of downtrodden community trust is organizing samuhika vivahalu, samuhika annaprasana, samuhika srimanthalu every year.

Name: ShriJGCoOpHospitalandResearchInstituteLtdGhataprabha
Major_Activities1: We are running well equipped Allopathy & Ayurvedic Hospital with total bed strength (150+220) 370. We are also running Naturopathy and Yoga Centre with provision for 50 indoor admissions & 30% of beds are reserved for free treatment to poor patients. All maternity cases & Poor Patients are provided free food & free medicines for very poor patients. 1st & 2nd delivery services are free. Immunisations services to children and pregnant women are free. Free services for Family Planning Programmes Working women Hostel accommodating 96 working women is functioning excellently. Reguralerly we conduct Free Health checkup and treatment camps in surrounding villages. Health education campus along with implementation of MCH Progremmes in nearby villages are conducted free of cost. Approximately 8 to 10 such camps arranged per year. GNM, B.Sc & M.Sc Nursing courses are provided, for development & empowerment of women. Separate Hostels are provided for Male & Female students. Various clinical courses are conducted by Institute. As per Government guidelines, specific No. of seats in these courses are reserved for SC & ST Students. M.Sc Nursing courses are being conducted in 1) Pediatric 2) Medical Surgical 3) O.B.G Services. We conduct various community health awareness programmes, to provide guidance for healthy life style practices, healthy food habits. We provide awareness regarding clarifications of false & wrong beliefs & ideas, about health related issues. We always strive to provide, awareness regarding availability of various health services in the nearby villages & see to it that, the community people actually participate in community health programmes.

Name: CONSUMER PROTECTION COUNCIL ROURKELA
Major_Activities1: A consumer organisation with a difference. Instead of rendering advisory services alone, the Council since its inception, in 1985, has been taking up issues affecting them through the consumer courts and other means and feels proud to have provided relief to crores of people. These include: *Remedial action against short-filling of LPG in cooking gas refills; 184 Bottling Plants, of the 3 Oil Marketing Companies (IOCL, BPCL & HPCL), which were the root cause of the short-filling of LPG in the cooking gas refills have been automated, at a cost of about Rs. 300 crores, by the Ministry of Petroleum and Chemicals. The quantified loss of nearly Rs. 750 crores per year to the consumers, across the country has been taken care by this upgradation. This was due to the Original Petition of the Council, initiated in 2001, before the National Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission (NCDRC); *Won an important case against the Rourkela Development Authority and secured financial relief for a group of individuals, against violation of Plan and Specifications in the construction of the houses and delay in handing over the possession; *Obtained a separate District Forum for Rourkela, though it is not the district headquarters, which otherwise necessitated the entire Rourkela population to approach the Forum, situated at Sundergarh, a place 100 kms. away; *Rerouting of Dhanbad-Alleppey Express Train through Chennai Central; *Campaigned against non-transferring of Excise Duty concessions (to the consumers) extended by the Union government to the industry; *Better upkeep of the Railway coaches of Utkal Kalinga Express and other trains; *Reintroduction of Ac Chair Car in Ispat Express and elimination of unfair trade practice by the SE Railway; *Refunding of Booking Advance by M/s LML and APSL; and *many more. To educate the consumers and create an awareness, the Council has been publishing its monthly, ADVANTAGE CONSUMER, for the last 28 years. Its website www.advantageconsumer.com, with a collection of important consumer dispute judgements of the National Commission and the Apex Court, has been serving the consumers, for the past 16 years, as a store house of information as to how the Consumer Protection Act can help the common man to redress his grievances. The Chief Mentor, has been answering and guiding the consumers across the country, FREE OF COST, ever since the website of the Council became operational in March 2000. The Council has redressed over 1500 individual complaints, through its own ADR mechanism. The innovative approach of the Council, whether it be putting up huge sign-boards (way back in 1989), to educate the consumers, or filing ever class action complaint in the State Commission, Orissa, (LML and APSL cases, 1989), have remained trail blazers for others to follow. All these had been done without any institutional funding, either from within the country or outside it.

Name: THE WOMEN EMPOWERMENT ORGANISATION TWEO
Major_Activities1: The organisation had conducted 5 days training and awareness programme on SHGs at Organisation Training Hall. The main objective of the training is to improve the role of the leaders of women Self Help Group and to develop activity of book keeping and accountancy knowledge among the Secretary, President and treasurer respectively. Altogether 35 women leaders were participated in the said programme. The organisation had organised 5 days Family Counselling Programme. Resource from the concerned Department had provided their valuable support in this programme. The Programme was successfully conducted. In order to upgrade the modern technique and skill, the Organisation has conducted a three month Handloom and Handicraft cum Production at Imphal West District in 2015. During the training programme skill trainer from Concerned Department demonstrated with modern tools and equipment and designs. The programme was participated by 30 women from the area and distributed training materials and training by products and finished products are of the income source of the organisation. A one day workshop on Women and Child labour Welfare Programme has been conducted on the importance of food and nutrition for pregnant women at the premises of the association on 2014. About 85 participants including community leaders and students took part in the programme. IEC and other related leaflet publish by the Forest and Environment was also distributed to the participants. Two days Handicapped Women and Child Welfare Programme were organised at Thangmeiband Yumnam Leikai, Imphal West District. Resource from concerned Department had provided their valuable support in this programme. Free health check-up and medicines were mobilized from the Medical Representatives and 84 patients were benefited from this programme. To advance and facilitate the rural students in bringing quality education in the state the organisation organised a Library awareness Programme. The programme entertained students from Class 5-12 and above. 12 committed professional teachers conducted the campaign of which the teachers volunteered to render their services during the programme. The organisation conducted a programme by engaging 2 resource persons on the theme of Adult Education to the Women Labourer about the concept of reading and writing and calculating arithmetic method.40 students were choosen from economically backwards families benefited from the said training programme.

Name: Elixir Foundation
Major_Activities1: 1. Balakalakaar - An Artist in Every Child: 1000+ Underprivileged Kids were benefited and 40 Students were given a scholarship of Rs 10000 each. 2. Roshan Up Lives: Awareness Documentary to support street people and reduce pollution. Blankets were also distributed to nearly 200 people. 3. World Environment Day: Day celebration to promote environment conservation by tree distribution in the vicinity and creating a documentary for visual promotions. 4. Women Transforming India: Our President nominated Muskaan Ahirwar and she was awarded by NITI Aayog for her contribution towards the society for running a library. 5. Women Higher Education for Peace, Vienna Forum: Our President represented India at United Nation HQ, Vienna in 2016. 6. Live With Bapu: Promoted Gandhian Values by organising a Poster Making Competition with participation of 600+ youths from schools and colleges. 7. Statue Cleaning: Cleaned nearly 200 Statues of National Icons across India on Independence Day and paid tribute to the national icons. 8. Walk for Freedom: Organised a walk with titles of freedom across 7 states of India with a huge participation from youths. 70 Titles of freedom were showcased as India completed 70 years of freedom. 9. Joy of Giving: Close to 2000 clothes were collected as a part of Joy of Giving Week and were donated to the needy on the eve of Diwali. 10. National Youth Award: The President of Elixir Foundation was awarded with National Youth Award for his exceptional services towards Community Welfare. 11. Indian Delegation to Bahrain: Madhish Parikh, President of Elixir Foundation was chosen by the Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports, Government of India and represented India at Bahrain. 12. Anti Corruption Pledge: The Foundation Members actively participated in the Integrity Pledge initiated by Central Vigilance Commission and appealed other citizens to do the same. 13. Youth Development Programmes: The foundation have actively executed various Leadership and Youth Development Programmes at various colleges and institutes in Ahmedabad. 14. Global Village: The foundation has partnered with AIESEC, World’s largest Youth Run Organisation and organised Global Village where in nearly 70 International Interns came to Ahmedabad and promoted International Integration.

Name: Jaypee Institute of Information Technology
Major_Activities1: Jaypee Institute of Information Technology, Noida was established in the year 2001 and has been declared as a “Deemed to be University” under Section 3 of UGC Act 1956 in the year 2004. JIIT’s state-of-the-art, environmentally conditioned campus comprises smart buildings with Wi-Fi connectivity covering the Academic Block, Business School cum Research Block, Faculty Residences, Student Hostels and Annapurna. Well equipped modern laboratories and an intellectually stocked Learning Resource Centre with books and E-Resources provide a pleasant and stimulating ambience. JIIT has been constantly ranked amongst the top engineering college in Delhi NCR. Recently it has been ranked among top Engineering Colleges in India by Edu Rand 2014 Engineering College Rankings.

Name: SARRP
Major_Activities1: SARRP (Spreading Awareness on Reptiles and Rehabilitation Programe) is an NGO registered in the year 2010, which works for reptiles, wild birds and other wildlife cause. However the main agenda of our organization is to rescue reptiles, wild birds etc who are encroaching into suburb / city and to educate people to avoid mishaps. Few members are working from more than decade and have dedicated their time and experience to help human population understand the vital importance of nature and its ecological balance. SARRP NGO has more than 100 dedicated volunteers which perform various activities from rescue missions to awareness campaigns. Many times it happens that wild birds / reptiles etc dwell in human captivity which creates danger for both, and this is when volunteers of SARRP takes charge by rescuing the animal and saving life of both animal and human, thus avoiding the chances of accidents like snake bites or other casualties.

Name: BUDHUVIR EDUCATIONAL TRUST
Major_Activities1: We initially started as to impart technical education, industrial training and self-employment training to interested youths to reduce unemployment. Thereafter, we took up and extended relief measures in the time of drought, flood, famine, earthquake, accident etc. and sponsor rehabilitation program in need. Then, we started providing assistance to rural poor and work for the welfare of the disadvantaged sections of the society like the SC/ST, OBC, Minorities and women. Also, ensured the neglected children of working and ailing mothers in a safe environment by providing nutrition, healthcare, education and recreation for mental and physical development of the poor children. We also helped to visualise to create a value added societies based on social justice unity, integrity, equality, peace, trust, freedom of their community organization, participation and empowerment by providing equal access to right to food, clothing, shelter, education, health and information to reach at a poor men, women and old person . Furthermore, we started providing life skill training such as planning for better business, vermin composting, mushroom, vegetable cultivation etc. We help provide product & services, credit, linkage of organic farming, marketing, packaging, processing and their entitlement benefits. At time we have extended Legal aid & care assistance to the street children, orphans, destitute, senior citizens, physically challenged people, child labour, sex workers, bonded labourers etc. We also train to remain ever prepared to have control over malaria, dengue diarrhea sickle cell, HIV/AIDS, and such deadly diseases, etc. that irrupts the community. We also organize thrift and credit programs among the women for formation of Self-help Groups. We propagate carry on developmental activities in socio economic, educational, health, agricultural and other allied fields for the welfare of the weaker section of the society in general. We have undertaken and assist in development program and projects among the poor, needy, and backward under privileged and handicapped irrespective of caste, creed, or color by itself or in collaboration with others.

Name: MAA SARASWATI EDUCATIONAL TRUST
Major_Activities1: Maa Saraswati Educational Trust is registered in the state of Haryana on 15th March 2002. The promoters of the Trust are highly qualified persons, having vast experience in the field of education, who are dedicated to produce excellent and quality technical education based on moral values and ethics. The main objective of the trust is to develop skilled and educated manpower in the area where there is acute shortage. The Trust aims at making its institutions one of the best educational institutions in the country to enable its students to acquire top places in the national and international market In a short span, the Trust has been able to achieve success and command respect in the eyes of the people of the region with its non-profit educational and charitable activities in the region. During the session 2009-10, Health Care Mela was organized by HGPI in which a team of highly qualified 12 doctors, specialists in their respective fields provided consultancy to more than a thousand patients belonging to weaker sections of the society from the surrounding rural areas. On the same day a blood donation camp was also organized where more than two hundred bottles of blood were collected by the team of doctors from PGI, Chandigarh. The institutions run by the Trust command respect and affection not only in Himachal Pradesh but also in the neighboring states. The students come from Himachal Pradesh, Haryana, Punjab, Chandigarh, Uttar Pradesh, Uttrakhand, Bihar, Jammu & Kashmir & North-East States etc. to study professional courses run by Himalayan Group of Professional Institutions. The primary aims and objects of the Trust are to provide, offer, promote and disseminate education at all levels of primary, middle, higher secondary and higher education. As per aims and objects, the trust is in process of initiating educational institutions to promote education in basic disciplines like Medical & Life sciences for which the LOI from Govt. of HP and the approval from medical council of India has been obtained. The Trust is ever willing to offer high quality and standardized education to needy students’ at most affordable rates with reservation for poor and weaker class students, handicapped and disadvantaged students as well as different type of scholarship for the needy and meritorious student. At the same time trust is willing to produce highly calibrated student from its institutes.

Name: THE SPASTICS SOCIETY OF TAMILNADU
Major_Activities1: The Spastics Society of Tamilnadu (SPASTN) empowers and enables disabled people to reach their full potential through Education, Training and Employment. Our activities begin with awareness-creation; go on to the screening of newborn babies in Primary Health Centers and Government Hospitals. We offer a wide range of services to parents of disabled children from special schools to Integration/ Inclusive education systems and job-orientated training programmes. We also promote self-help groups. We focus strongly on improving access for the disabled by promoting a barrier free environment. We collaborate with mainstream sectors like Health, Education, Rural Development, Integrated Child development Scheme (ICDS), Social Welfare, Transport, universities, social defence and women’s development. We work towards full inclusion of disabled persons, parents and family members as stakeholders in the organization. Our Community Based Rehabilitation programmes and Center Based Rehabilitation programmes, encourages the formation of independent Self Help Groups and Parents Associations. We are committed to Human Resource Development through training of Parents, Special Educators, Therapists, Government Personnel, Educators and Volunteers. We have promoted Low Cost Technology for the development of mobility and adaptive devices for persons with disabilities. We educate rural people on the rights of the disabled through Puppet Shows, Street Plays and Villupattu, (popular folk songs with disability issues tuned to hit film songs). At the core of everything that SPASTN undertakes, is the passionate belief in the dignity of human life. It is for this, which SPASTN champions for the Rights of disabled persons, the right to life, to information, to education, to health, to employment, to social security, to recreation, and to full participation. Our logo, two interlinked hands, embodies the synergistic linkages and co-operation between persons with disabilities, their families and the community, taking everyone towards our vision of an inclusive society

Name: HINDUSTHAN EDUCATIONAL AND CHARITABLE TRUST
Major_Activities1: Hindusthan Educational and Charitable Trust was founded in the year 1992 by the eminent Industrialist and Philanthropist, Shri T.S.R Khannaiyann. The Trust is being managed by the Secretary, Smt. Sarasuwathi Khannaiyann, Joint Secretary Smt. Priya Satish Prabu and Trustee Shri.K.Sakthivel Raja. Since its inception the Trust has involved itself in benevolent activities for inculcating quality education by promoting various types of Educational Institutions. Hindusthan College of Arts & Science pursues a philosophy of perpetual acquisition of knowledge. Apart from academic curriculum, equally important is the policy to provide value based education and to bring out the hidden potential in students that equip them to approach life with optimism. The main motive of the Hindusthan Trust is to serve the needy. The Trust adopts poor children and offers free education. It also offers assistance and guidance pertaining to higher studies. The Trust also helps them to earn a living. The Trust motivates the rankholders and toppers by providing financial assistance. Started in the year 1998 with 300 students and 4 departments with 20 faculty members, the college has grown from strength to strength. Now the college has 18 UG Programmes and 13 PG Programmes and 13 Research Programmes. The reason for its success in such a short time is the excellent location of the college, its proximity to the railway station, the bus stand and the airport. Moreover, the college has earned a sound reputation for producing 100 percent results in most of its programmes and 100 percent placements for the students. In a short span of 14 years, the college has been able to produce several rank holders including 1st rank at the Bharathiar University. The College places its emphasis on Academic excellence which is the main aim of the dedicated staff and students. Every year the college strives to achieve maximum number of university ranks. The Visual Communication programme offered by HICAS is crowned to be “ The Best “ among all colleges in Western Region by the Media. The NSS Volunteers work in close association with the various social organizations serving the society. The Youth Red Cross is actively engaged in blood donation programmes and various other social services for the up-liftment of the downtrodden. National Level Seminars like EXEMPLAR, CLUSTERS, HIFEAST, BIMBAM, BIO-SUMMIT, INFO-ICONS, ASTOUND, HI-COM, etc. are some of the frequent academic activities conducted to enhance the knowledge of the students. Inter Collegiate Programmes like HILARICAS is conducted every year to encourage the students in activities other than academics. Over 100 colleges across the state and other states used to participate and win prizes upto one lakh.

Name: Dakshin Dinajpur Society of People Living with HIV AIDS
Major_Activities1: To access all people living with HIV/AIDs in Dakshin Dibnajpur bring them under one Umbrella , and help them live a more productive life with dignity and self confidence and improve the Survival and Quality of life of PLHIV, To function as a coalition of community based organization and Block level network of people living with HIV/AIDS in Dakshin Dinajpur. To acquire, establish, start, aid ,run, maintain or manage educational institutes ,libraries for the benefit of the public. To arrange and organic lectures, debates, discussions, seminars & excursions for diffusion of knowledge. To publish or cause to be published useful literatures, magazines, etc, without profit motive. To study, cultivate and demonstrate draft of music and dancing. To promote and encourage advancement of literary, cultural, political, religious & scientific education. To help the Needy student of all communities for the prosecution studies. To help the age ,sick ,helpless and indigent persons. To work for the happiness of the down trodden needy people for their primary needs such as food ,cloth ,education and shelter etc. To import and develop social awareness among the illiterate women and men by organizing awareness camps from time to time. To organic an ambulance for free rendering service to the needy patients. To establish and maintain basic and adult education centre to remove the illiteracy .To arrange and organize dead body carrier for free rendering service to help the needy people of the society .To open charitable dispensaries ,first aid centre ,blood donation camp from time to time and to generate awareness amongst people suffering from Thalasimia, Cancer disease etc. To arrange and organize education on computer both in theoretical and practical classes among the needy students of the society without profit motive .To render relief to the suffering in times of famine, flood, drought, earthquake and other natural calamities. To educate the people about pollution and arrange plantation of trees in the locality to make the world green. To arrange and organize old age home to help the needy people of the society without profit motive. To arrange for medical treatment to the Deaf & Dumb and handicapped persons by rendering qualified doctors, medicines and other allied articles free of cost. To help the people in marriage , funeral and cremation of the dead. To help the organize self-help group based program for augmentation of livelihood opportunities of the people at the grass root level as being beneficial to the public or to a section of public.
