Name: INDIAN ACADEMY OF SOCIAL SCIENCES
Major_Activities1: Indian Academy of Social Sciences (ISSA) organizes Indian Social Science Congress, State Social Science Congresses, Local /Regional/National/International Seminars/symposia/ workshops/colloquia, training programmes. It has three Research Centres, namely, Rural Development Study Centre, Survey Research Centre, ISSA Silver Jubilee Peoples Centre for the Theoretical and Policy Research. It publishes quarterly research journal named Bhartiya Samajik Chintan and proposes to publish at least one science journal in each Indian language. ISSA initiated organization of Indian Social Science Congress in 1976. since then 39 sessions of Indian Social Science Congress have been held in different parts of India and its 40th session is scheduled to be held between Dec 19-23, 2016 at University of Mysore, Mysuru. UGC recognizes Indian Social Science Congress on par with Indian Science Congress, Prof. B. M. Hegde, Padam Bhushan awardee of 2010, is currently its President. ISSA has young Scientists division which organizes All India Young Scientists Convention. So far five sessions of Young Scientists Convention have been held and its sixth session is scheduled to be held in December 22-23, 2016 at University of Mysore. Bharatiya Samajik Chintan is being published since 1976. Samayik Samajik Chintan was published for two consecutive years in late 1980’s. It had to be stopped because of non-availability of financial resources. It publishes Social Science Abstracts every year. So far 39 volumes of social science abstracts have been published. Over 60 books/monographs have been published till today and half dozen are in different stages of editing. It also organizes B. V. Rangarao Memorial Lecture and awards A. K. Tharien Gold Medal, Prof. P. V. Sukhanta Gold Medal, Basants Sarkar Gold Medal, Ashok Maiti Gold Medal and Gauri Shankar Gold Medal. It is planning to established National Science Translation Centre (NSTC) for producing science books, monograph, Research Papers in all Indian languages for promoting creativity in science. Indian Academy of Social Sciences aims at discovering, developing and disseminating science of Nature-Humans-Society. It considers science as social and boundryless. It brings all subject/disciplines/branches of Science of Nature-Humans-Society together. Unity of science is its mission. Indian Academy of Social Sciences seeks to enable peoples of India to enjoy higher material, social, cultural and spiritual life through science. Indian Academy of Social Sciences is the first national Science Academy of Democratic Republic of India and fourth in chronicle order. It was established on August 15, 1974 with its registered headquarters at Allahabad. Today it is a 42 year old most prestigious national Science Academy. Its new name Indian Social Science Academy (ISSA) will be effective from April 01, 2017.

Name: Association for Social Health In India Birbhum Pusparag Niketan
Major_Activities1: Association for Social Health in India (ASHI) Birbhum Branch, Pusparag Niketan, Rampurhat, Nischintapur is one of the premier voluntary organisation established in 1993 by the eminent Social worker and freedom fighter Dr. Phulrenu Guha and Maya Ghosh to combat against immoral trafficking and other exploitation and atrocities against the women and girls in society. This organisation has been running a Short-Stay-Home since May, 1993 under the Grant-in-Aid scheme of “The Central Social Welfare Board, Ministry of Women and Child Development, Govt. of India” and affiliated by the Association for Social Health in India, West Bengal Branch, Kolkata. It is social welfare, non-profitable and non-Govt. organization Pusparag Niketan Short-Stay-Home is a temporary shelter for women and girls in the age group of 15-35 yrs, who are victims of social and family atrocities, family mal-adjustment, discord or any in moral danger. It has considerably helped such vulnerable women and girls who are coming from weaker section of the society and different Govt. corners through Court, Local & District Administration etc. There women can stay for three years for free of cost boarding, lodging, clothing, medical treatment, protection and are helped in build-up their future through well equipped vocational trainings and employment as per their capabilities and are assisted by the key staffs of Home. The day-to-day affairs of the Home are being managed by the key staffs of Home. Home Committee/Home Management Committee of “Short-Stay-Home” is being formed amongst the members of the Executive Committee, Govt. Officers and key staffs of this Home Every year the members, staffs and inmates are being observed the national programmes i.e. Independence Day on 15th August and The Republic Day on 26th January with national songs. We also celebrated International Women’s Day on 8th March. There is a part-time medical Doctor, who visits once in a week, medically checked the inmates and prescribed them with necessary medicines. After admission of all inmates we made necessary arrangement for VDRL/HIV test from Rampurhat Health District Hospital at Rampurhat. We also provide Psychiatric treatment of our mentally challenged inmates at Suri Sadar Hospital Birbhum with help of the Addl. District Magistrate (Dev.) and the Sub-Divisional Officer Rampurhat Birbhum. This Home provides different trainings regularly in tailoring, knitting, embroidery etc free of cost within this Home campus under care of the trained instructors. We also provides six months vocational tailoring training out side the Home under WB State Council of technical and Vocational Education & Skill Development, Karigori Bhavan, New Town, Rajarhat, Kolkata and also the few inmates are attending College and School regularly. The Home has also provided daily newspaper. There is a local cable connection T.V. Ludo etc. and also arranged picnic and tour every year for recreation of the Home residents.

Name: Keshab Smarak Sanskriti Surabhi
Major_Activities1: The activities Performed by Keshab Smarak Sanskriti Surabhi are as follows : The Samiti is Conducting regular Allopathic Medical Camps in different places of Barak Valley. Free medicines are also proving to the patients. A Mobile Medical Van is launched by the Samiti to bring doctors at the remote corner of the region and to cater the needs of the poor people for getting better health services. This Samiti celebrated Vishwa Yoga Divas with full zeal & enthusiasm. The two day Yoga Divas was inaugurated in G.C. College Auditorium, Silchar by the Honorable Governor of Assam, Shri P.B. Acharya on 20th June 2015. To eradicate Diabetes, a Programme was taken for 7 days in Silchar. Sri Sumanta Chandwarkar, a famous Yoga Teacher from Maharastra taught the technique of Yoga to the participants in the camp which started on 22nd June, 2015. About 200 members were present in the function & 61 No. of Patients attended the Camp To Provide medical assistance to the residents of remote areas, Keshab Smarak Sanskriti Surabhi had Launched Dhanwantari Seva Yatra Progamme in Barak Valley in the month of May 2015 & February 2016 respectively. A Joint programme of Seva Bharati Purbanchal & National Medical Organization, A total of 15 doctors of NMO came from across India to provide Medical Treatment to the Patients of Rural Area in Barak Valley & Mizoram. The No. of Camps were about 20 & Patients were about 4000. Besides giving Treatment, Medicines were distributed amongst the patients free of cost. 3 numbers of Computer Training centre are running by the samity at 3 differnt places. On 20th June 2015, the Honorable Governor of Assam Inaugurated Gramin Computer Training Centre under patronage of Surabhi. Training Centre for Sewing machine for ladies are running at 4 centres in Assam and Mizoram. House building materials and blankets as well as mosquito nets were provided to the victims of different natural calamities Surabhi Databbya Homoeo Treatment Centre is giving its service in Kalibari Char area of Silchar. Every Friday, Dr. Subhadip Kar renders free Service to the residents of that area through checkup & distributing Medicines free of cost. This Yojna is presently running in Assam, Tripura and Mizoram states in 754 centres running by 1384 Arogya Mitras. They are acting as rural health worker aiming to serve rural population. Surabhi Tabla School in running in Surabhi Karalaya under the Patronage of Surabhi Kalakendra. Every Sunday Sri Subhrajit Kar (Executive Member, K.S.S.S) imparts training to students free of cost. A Surabhi Yoga Center is successfully going on in Narshingpur at Cachar. Besides Yoga camps are organised at different locations of Assam and Tripura. On 21st Feb, 2016 a programme on Corneal Blindness Free India & Eye Donation was jointly organized by us & Barak Netradaan Sankalp Abhiyan Samiti under the initiative of SAKSHAM.

Name: NARSINGH SWAIN MEMORIAL TRUST
Major_Activities1: ACHIEVEMENTS OF NARSINGH SWAIN MEMORIAL TRUST The major achievement of the N Swain Memorial Trust is the Aakar [Shape] Asha [Hope] a Super-Specialty hospital for Reconstructive surgery with a built –up area of 55,000 sq.ft. in three floors on 2 acres in a strategic location on NH7, the crowded area of once Asia’s biggest housing localities that is Kukatpally, Hyderabad with an investment of around Rs. 9 crore. The one of its kind project won an award at the 2nd ISB iDiya competition in 2012. Aakar Asha is a referral Centre for Reconstructive Surgery. Apart from Reconstructive Plastic Surgery Orthopedics, Cancer and Pediatric Reconstructive surgeries are done. Specialized services like Oral and Maxillofacial surgery, Dermatology services play a significant role. The allied specialized services that are required for all round requirement of the patient like: Anesthesiologists and Pain management specialists, Physician and Neurologist, Pediatrician, General and Laparoscopic Surgeons and ENT surgeon provide the support services needed for the delightful experience of poor patients during their stay at the Hospital. A state of art Physical Rehab department completes the picture. The hospital has its own 24 x 7 Pharmacy, Diagnostic facilities (clinical pathology, biochemistry and Radiology with Color Doppler), with 3 Operating Theaters [including laminar theater as per NABH guideline], 2 ICUs and Post Op area. It has a capacity of 130 beds with 51 beds in operation of three different categories: General, Sharing and Single rooms other than ICU beds. Besides, the hospital has Dormitory facilities for accommodation of the attendants of the patient during treatment period with in the premises. The kitchen and cafeteria within the premises take care of the patients and their attendant’s dietary needs and provide food for the patient’s attendants. The hospital was built to take care of patient from undivided Andhra Pradesh [presently Telangana and Andhra Pradesh], where the incidence of deformities are high. However, the patient from the neighboring states are been treated with same care and sincerity. The Trust, guided by its objectives, has strived to work for the physically disabled, especially those below poverty line. Activities include creating awareness amongst stakeholders about reconstructive surgery bringing about a transformation in the lives of the physically disabled and helping to identify the beneficiaries; screening camps and reconstructive surgery camps; education and training of doctors and the public. Since 2001, we have conducted more than 30 awareness camps and have distributed literature pertaining to knowledge of physical disability and availability of treatment. No less than 20 free screening camps have been conducted wherein around 1400 persons have been screened for undergoing surgery for physical disability and 900 Physically Disabled persons have undergone reconstructive surgery free of cost since inception of the Trust. 11 Continuing Medical Education programs have been conducted, 8 of which have been the innovative Basic Surgical Skills workshops in which about 250 doctors have been trained hands on. 1 workshop on physiotherapy and a Lifesavers program for first responders have been conducted

Name: The Organisation For Women and Rural Development
Major_Activities1: TOWARD is a reputed state-level Research oriented developmental organization, working towards sustainable development process through participatory efforts of development activities, training and research since 1994. It is having a strong Networking system all over the State and well equipped infrastructure facilities with a sufficient number of multi disciplinary faculties. It is a multi-disciplinary body, which focuses on the problems of poor, weaker, distressed and deprived sections of the society in the development, protection and conservation of natural resources, promotion of sustainable livelihood and protection of human rights at all levels. The Thrust areas of- TOWARD are as Follows :-  Research/ Evaluation/Impact Assessment Studies/ Seminars/ Workshops/ Baseline Survey etc.  Organizing Entrepreneurship Skill up gradation Training specially for poor and unemployed youth(women) for augmentation of their socio-economic status  Working for SHG-Promotion and Organizing Entrepreneurship Development Programme (EDP) for creating employment opportunities for rural poor women, SC/ST and EWS people as well as for the poor artisans for revival of languishing crafts .  Marketing of Rural based products such as : Handicrafts / Handloom items and other Village Industries Products etc. by way of making arrangement with like minded agencies and also by participating in the exhibition and festivals.  We also undertake various awareness, educational and documentation activities for creating confidence and self status among the rural poor and neglected groups of women like : SC/ST/ Minority etc.  Undertaking various art & cultural programmes among the school and college students for preservation of traditional culture of our state and promotion of national integration and restoration of unity among the diversity & many more Need Based Action oriented Socio-economic and Development Research Studies are being conducted in the field of :- • Human Resource Development • Natural Resource Development • Social Survey and Studies • Feasibility Studies Processing of Data and documentation • Rural Development, • Women empowerment • Rehabilitation and Reconstruction, • Skill upgradation development, • Welfare activities for all round development of Scheduled Tribe, Scheduled Caste, OBC & Minorities • Educational Development, • Animal Welfare Activities, • Environmental Protection, • Eradication of untouchability, TOWARD has got enormous experience in the field of Research, Evaluation, Monitoring, Seminar, Workshop, Skill Up Gradation Training, Entrepreneurship Development Programme(EDP) ,Designing Development Training Of Languishing Tribal Art & Craft, Income Generation Programme For SHG Beneficiaries, Project Formulation & Documentation Works etc . Our Organization has been funded by several Ministries / Departments of both GoI & Govt. of Odisha like: • Ministry of Tribal Affairs • Ministry of Women & Child Development • Ministry of HRD • Ministry of Agriculture • Ministry of Culture & Tourism • Ministry of Food Processing Industries • Dept. of SC/ST, Govt. of Orissa • Directorate of Industries, Govt. of Orissa • State Mission Directorate, NMFP • Many other funding agencies. Entrepreneurship Development Programme (EDP) Training on Food & Agro Processing Industries At: • Keonjhar, • Dhenkanal, • Jagatsinghpur Districts State Level Workshop On Violence Against Women State Level Workshop On Tribal Education With Special Reference To Women Education Study On Status Of Migrant Women Labour Of Orissa Study On Functioning Of S.H.G. For Women In Orissa. Collection & Publication Of The Folk Tales Of JUANG- A Primitive Tribe Of Orissa. Integrated National Horticulture Programme Functioning of Coir-Geo Textile Products at Keonjhar district of Orissa. Vocational Training On Coir Products to SC Women Of Bhubaneswar Municipal Corporation Evaluation Study of Vocational Training Centre In Tribal Areas of Orissa. Skill Up gradation Training on Handloom Weaving to women beneficiaries conducting base line survey, for revival of Dongriakondha weaving technique of shawal, at Rayagada, for involving these PTG tribes in various socio-economic programmes of state / central government, baseline survey of brass & bell metal artisans of ganjam district and coverage of health insurance under rajiv gandhi swatha bima yojana organizing fruits & vegetable preservation training camps for the adolescents & women beneficiaries at Rayagada district, organized a number of awareness/ sensitization camps at Rayagada to create more & more vibrant entrepreneurs in the agrifood processing sectors / village industries sectors One day Awareness Camp for revival of Dongria Kond weaving Textile Shawl Participated at the State level Agri Food Exhibition-15, Bhubaneswar Evaluation studies of various centrally sponsored schemes Livelihood project of the Primitive Tribal Group of Malkangiri district – Didayi Tribel Project Report preparation, EM-I /II Regisatin , Online Registration , help the entrepreneurs to participate in the state/national level exhibition , bank loan follow-up ,TIN/VAT/IT Return ,Land /Shedallotment arrangement etc.

Name: Anarghya
Major_Activities1: We have been involved in; -Motivating and recruiting blood donors ensuring that they voluntarily donate their blood during the times of emergency and till date several hundreds of donations have successfully happened throughout India especially in Andhra Pradesh and Telangana saving several lives. -Special interactive sessions with Girls and women to educate them on menstrual hygiene management and awareness. -Conducting medical camps and awareness campaigns in Govt. Schools, colleges, rural areas etc., along with required medicines. -Renovation of poor toilets especially in educational institutions, ensuring access to safe and clean toilets while maintaining proper sanitation, safe drinking water etc. -Customized personality development sessions for children both at educational institutions and orphanages/shelter homes. -Interactive activities for mentally retarded, differently abled and elderly/aged people -Clothes donation to all kinds of needy people in regular intervals -Blanket donations to the shelter less people and to the needy -Revival of the distraught -Food donation drives

Name: SOCIETY FOR SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE AND FOREST ECOLOGY
Major_Activities1: Facilitate the process, which enable the people to adopt sustainable, environment friendly, equitable and cost effective livelihood systems. Achievements are - SAFE has worked with 1892 ground water user families and equipped 2483 ground water user farmers with necessary data, skills and knowledge to manage ground water resources available to them in sustainable manner. Farmer training programs on different PHM modules. Formation of community based organization at Hydological Unit Level and at habitation level - Ground Water Management Committees. Data collection and monitoring by farmers. Display an dissemination of data at village level. Training in sustainable agriculture practices and water saving technics. Organizing year long farmer schools. Organizing CWB workshops at the end of Kharif. Crop plans and adoption. Capacity building and women participation in ground water management. Functional linkages between CBOs and line department. Complete study on local and scientific knowledge on impacts of climate variability, change on natural resources in Andhra Pradesh. Local monitoring system of climate variability and its impacts operation in at least 9 CBOs in pilot HUs collecting data on at least 3 key indicators. CBOs with capacities to integrate climate variability adaptation measures in Sustainable Land and Water Management (SLWM). Farmers acquire skills in managing climate variability and testing adaptation technologies in farming systems of alternative adaptation technologies and practices in SLWM. Project lessons, results and product documents disseminated. In addition SAFE is also actively involved in organic agriculture for sustainable livelihood, bio-diversity of germ plasm conservation, seed multiplication with traditional technologies, market linkages, medicinal plants conservation.

Name: Balmaitri Sishu Sansthan
Major_Activities1: Our NGO have a vision to save child, save village and save nature.For save child we have established an english medium school which is the only english medium school in that region.we also have established an institute for higher education which includes certificate courses of computers. We also participated in national digital literacy mission and enroll 96 students. If we talk about saving village, because of better education the migration of villagers stopped who tend to take their kids to cities for higher education.We also run social awareness programs by doing theaters, nukad natak.We also organise medical camps for eye care, dental and other on regular intervals. We are also working in a field of woman empowerment, we are giving free swing training to the girls or ladies and help them to create there own source of income.We have given employment to more then 30 people directly if we talk about saving nature then every year we plant new tree and last year we have plant more then 100 plants on the road ends to avoid land slide.

Name: Friends of Tribals Society
Major_Activities1: Friends of Tribals Society (FTS) was established in 1989 at Kolkata by some eminent philanthropists with the object of all-round development of tribals in our country. Following Swami Vivekanand’s dictum ‘Where the child cannot come to the school, the school must go to the child’ the founding members of FTS started the concept of One Teacher Schools (Ekal Vidyalalya) wherein a teacher, usually an educated young person from the village, teaches about 25-30 children of class 1, 2 and 3. These informal schools are conducted for three hours every day and apart from elementary education the children are also imparted basic health training including yoga and exercise and knowledge of Indian culture and heritage and handicrafts etc. Training of these teachers is also done once every month and for five days every six months. As on September 30, 2016 FTS along with its associate organizations were running 52453 schools in the remote villages across the country and FTS alone was running 29463 schools. Monitoring of running of these schools is done by an intricate system of administration at state, district and sub district level and the data on running and working of the schools in centrally collected at the society’s head office and analysed every month. With time and in keeping with the changing needs of the times, FTS has also expanded the scope of its work in the villages. Under Awareness Education, they discuss various issues for benefit of the village like eradication of alcoholism, settlement of their mutual issues and the government schemes for the benefit of the villagers.This programme creates a very healthy atmosphere in the village. Whenever necessary, FTS sewabratis help them in filing application under Right to Information Act. (RTI). Moreover the scope of education was expanded not only to include health and hygiene but also development education. Under development education the villagers are encouraged to produce fertilizer from cow dung and Pesticides from cow urine. The children of FTS schools are encouraged to plant at least one sapling each year. These are normally planted in and around the houses of the villagers so that they can take care of the sapling and also become owner of the trees. This also develops a creative attitude among children. Impact of FTS’ work: Due to the various activities run by FTS in the villages there is improvement in the state of education both for the children and the guardians. The villagers are gradually leading a more hygienic life, their financial condition is improving on account of various development activities. They are also getting rid of addiction to alcohol and the most important aspect is that with inculcation of moral values they also develop dedication to Mother Bharat.

To encourage national unity and create atmosphere to remove the social evils.

Name: SANGEET NIKETAN
Major_Activities1: Sangeet Niketan was established with the aim of education and propagation of Classical Music and Kathak Dance on 01-01-1950 by Shri Gulab Rai, Sangeet Vachaspati at 2666, Ballimaran, Delhi - 110006. The second branch of Sangeet Niketan was started during the year 1990 at G-365 Preet Vihar, Delhi - 110092 the third branch of Sangeet Niketan was started during the year 1997 at Malviya Nagar, New Delhi - 110017. The head office was subsequently transferred at G - 365, Preet Vihar, Delhi - 110092 in the year 2012. Sangeet Niketan, Delhi was Affiliated with Indira Kala Sangeet Vishwavidyalaya, Khairagarh (Chhattisgarh) During the year 1958. Since then, University Examinations are being conducted at Sangeet Niketan, Delhi every year. During the year 2015-16, 227 students were imparted education in Sangeet Niketan in various fields of Music i.e. Vocal Instrumental and Kathak Dance, out of which there were 31 boys and 196 girls. In the year 2015-16, University Examinations were held in February, 2016, in which 169 students appeared in the University Examinations of various classes. It is informed that out of 169 students, who appeared in the Examinations, 161 students have passed with flying colours. It is a matter of great pleasure that out of 161 passed students, most of them have secured First Division. Sangeet Niketan celebrated its 65th Annual Function on the 31st January, 2016 at LTG Auditorium, New Delhi. More than four hundred members of audience attended and appreciated the performances. In the Function more than 150 students participated and took active part in the field of Vocal, Instrumental and Kathak Dance programmes. The function was very much appreciated by the Chief Guest Dr. Sonal Mansingh, Padma Vibhushan and the audience as well as by the press.

Name: Umeed Welfare Foundation
Major_Activities1: Umeed was born with a vision of reaching out to differently-abled children in our society , as well as to their families. “Diffferently-abled” children are often referred to as “disabled,” “handicapped,” “mentally-retarded,” or simply as “special-needs children.” Umeed provides quality intervention for these children while also promoting increased societal awareness of their needs and increased sensitivity toward those needs. Umeed seeks to work towards a society which views each person as being of value and importance and to make a difference in the lives of children with disabilities as well as their families. Umeed provides quality intervention for these children while also promoting increased societal awareness and sensitivity towards their needs. The school seeks to build a society that cares equally for the needs and growth of each special child by admitting special children from all sections of society regardless of caste, creed, race, religion, economic and gender barriers. Umeed Foundation has around 30 children including the school as well as outreach. We charge fee for the parents who can afford the same. The fee is charged so that Umeed is able to sustain its basic costs as this field involves lots of costing. We also give education to the underprivileged section absolutely free. We also promote girl child education from weaker section. About 14 girls from near slum area have been given dress, school bag and books. Everyday evening classes are held for them so as to educate them atleast that much so that they are able to take a small but respectable job for themselves. The income that we receive is spent mainly on salaries of employees and consultants, developmental costs, maintenance, depreciation of furniture, electricity, the teaching learning materials that are bought for children etc. Some Umeed kids have been integrated in highly reputed mainstream schools like The Heritage, G D Goenka, DAV Public School , HDFC School, DPS and Adharshila The SAACAR unit children are taught vocational skills to lead an independent life. The achievement is that we have been able to reach out to many people through our products and create awareness about special needs. Kids are trained in sports to actively participate in Special Olympics. Various workshops by National and International speakers are conducted for parents as well as educators.

Name: Sanjivini Society for Mental Health
Major_Activities1: Sanjivini is Delhi’s premier non-profit organization that has, since 1976, tirelessly addressed the emotional and mental health needs of society through counselling and rehabilitation of persons afflicted with schizophrenia. Our work is primarily carried out at two main units - the Counselling or Crisis Intervention Unit and the Rehabilitation Centre. At these centres, primary interventions as well as community-based and preventive initiatives are carried out. Below is a brief write up about our various programmes: Crisis Intervention: This Unit provides free and confidential psycho-social counselling for a wide spectrum of emotional distress and mental health problems, ranging from self esteem issues, inter-personal problems, depression, suicide, substance abuse and severe mental disorders. Our trained volunteer counsellors carry out this counselling. Rehabilitation Centre: This pioneering programme, which works towards the rehabilitation of persons suffering from chronic schizophrenia, has become a module that is being replicated by many other institutions. It is a full day therapeutic facility, which uses therapy at the group, individual and family levels. Referral Service: Through extensive networking with other organizations, we have built up a huge referral service. Equipped with this, we help our clients to get legal, medical or other specialized help, as required by them. Community Outreach Programme: Over the years, the sustained efforts of our ongoing Community Outreach initiatives have been directed towards the goal of destigmatizing counselling by raising the awareness of the community about different aspects of emotional and mental health and the help available. Basic Counselling Skills Course: This annually conducted workshop equips helpers in the community such as teachers, doctors and counselors with skills not only to make them better helper but also helps them to build more awareness of self which further leads to better relationship. In recognition of our contribution to society, Sanjivini has been honoured with the Sanskriti Award for 1982 and the Delhi Government award for valuable services rendered in 1998.
issues_working_db: Health & Family Welfare,Any Other,

Name: Rural Area Development Trust
Major_Activities1: BACKGROUND OF THE ORGANISATION: The Rural Area Development Trust (RUADT) is a voluntary social service organization exclusively working for the rehabilitation of differently-abled people. It was set up in the village of B. Dharmathupatti in 1991, with the mission of identifying needy differently-abled chil-dren in the surrounding areas (around 10 villages) through awareness about disability and its implications for affected families and individuals. RUADT started its work with only 17 physically challenged children in 1996 (91-93 done basic survey in the Bodi Block and 93 –96 formation of women community and creating aware-ness about woman rights), providing basic amenities like foods, clothes, free medical treatment, transport, physiotherapy, and surgery. All these services were provided on, the surveyed need basis and are aimed at enabling the children to participate in community life and attend formal schooling. In 1997, RUADT started the Community Based Rehabilitation (CBR) Programme for per-sons with disabilities in rural areas. The programme was supported by German Doctor’s Commit-tee, Germany from 1997 to 2001, where 217 differently-abled persons (persons with disabili-ties including differently-abled children) were benefited by the CBR programme. An additional 619 individuals and their families were reached in another 28 villages with support from the CBR Forum, Bangalore. In 1999, the Miriam Dean Trust, U.K supported the RUADT’s differently-abled children programme, to which a programme for mentally challenged and Spastic Cerebral Palsy children was added, that included a strong focus on parents’ participation. In 2002, RUADT implemented the NPRPD (CBR) programme for the Department of Disa-bled Rehabilitation of the Government of Tamil Nadu in Bodinayakanur Block of Theni District. One MRW (Multi Rehabilitation Worker), 50 CBR employees, and 2,525 people with disabilities were involved in this programme. In 2004, we implemented a Day Care Centre at Uthamapalayam named Manjari Day Care Centre. The programme was supported by Nandri help for South India, Switzerland Home based rehabilitation programme was also supported by Nandri which opened doors for about 60 chil-dren. In 2005, Kamarajar Day Care centre was established to identify the children aged 0- 6 years affected by brain damage and growth retardation. After identifying the children, the EIC Rehabilitation treatment plan was discussed with our rehabilitation professionals according to the impairment. The treatment of Early Intervention centre includes Physiotherapy, Occupa-tional therapy, Special Education, Sensory integration and Play Therapy. In 2008, we replaced Kamarajar Day Care Centre to Pushparani Children’s Village which became permanent now. The Early intervention centre capacitates 50 – 65 children. The thera-py treatments, food and transportation charges are provided free of cost. Now the centre is elevated to special school and vocational training centre. Rural Area Development Trust is emerging to become a strong foundation with the help of our Board of Governors, reliable Donors, dedicated rehabilitation professionals, Caretakers, Well-wishers’ and Parents. MILESTONE: 1. 1991- registration o f the association and eco development programmes around 10 villages 2. 1993-94- started tailoring unit, training for women , IGP Programmes, pillow making, rexin bags making, health centres at korangani,Kottagudi and Mundhal. 3. 1996- Economical survey and identifyind differently abled children around 10 villages, 17 children were admitted in the residential programmes at chicken shed-rented building. 4. 1997- a small piece of land donated by founder for construction of children home. Bro.James Kimpton supported for construcion of children home building. DCF supported revenue e xpenditure for 30 children. German Doctor’s Committee, through Anu Desai, referred by Dr.Desai supported to the vehicle for transport for schooling. By the humble support by Bro.James , we did corrective surgery for 17 children and provided assistive devices to them. They were walking independently which made us happy. 5. 1998 -started community based rehabilitation for persons with disabilities around 10 villages, totally 217 beneficeries were benefitted by the programme by the year 2000. 6. 1999- the home registered at rehabilitation department, Chennai and Supervision and Control Act at social welfare department ,Chennai. 103 physically challenged children benefitted the by the programme. Miriam Dean Fund has been supporting the revenue expenditure and some of the capital expenditure. 7. 2000- Extension of community based rehabilitation at Cumbum Valley around 21 villages. We identified 618 beneficiaries supported by CBR Forum, Bangalore- Caritas India, New Delhi. 8. 2001- The Government of Tamil Nadu presented our secretary, S.Murugan, the State Level Best Social Worker. The District Collector presented the Best Institution Award. 9. 2002-We bought additional piece of land around 2.37 acres adjoining our main campus for the extension of mentally challenged rehabilitation programme. 10. 2003- Construction of new special school building at our new piece of land. We bought a new minibus for the transportation of our chidren . 11. 2004- We started a new Day Care Centre, name as Manjari for the mentally challenged children, Uthamapalayam Taluk, which is still benefitting around 30 children. 12. 2005- We started Kamarajar early intervention centre at Theni. 13. 2006- We started community programme with the support of Tamil Nadu Government ( Pudhu Vazhvu, SSA-IED) 14. 2007-The Tamil Nadu Government presented the State level Best Institution Award. 15. 2008- The Pushparani Children’s Village Construction 16. 2008 - Mobile Therapy Clinic 17. 2010- 2015 – Vocational Training Centre for adult Mentally Challenged persons.Bodinayakanur Taluk-(Infrastructure support by Japan Embassy, Revenue Expenditure suported by RTU- UK).Theni Taluk- ( Pushparani Vocational Training Centre supported by Nandri- Help for South India, Switzerland.) 18. 2014,Village Rehabilitation Therapy Centre, Dombuchery - BHC 19. 2015,Village Rehabilitation Therapy Centre, Veerapandi - BHC 20. 2016,Village Rehabilitation Therapy Centre, Bodinayakanur - GH ACHIEVEMENTS: 1. 2001-State level Best Social Worker Award 2. 2001 – District level Best Institution 3. 2007 – State Level Best Institution 4. 2008 - Athithanar Award for Lifetime Achievement 5. 2009 – Best Social Worker Award (Hindu Nadar Saraswathi College for Women) 6. 2010 – Best Institution Award ( Law Society) 7. 2014 – Best Social Worker Award (Theni Kalai Ilakiya Mandram) Registration and Recognition 1. Name: Centre for Applied Research and Extension
Major_Activities1: 1.Climate Smart Agriculture Executed pilots in 16 villages of Achampet Tq TS. Established Climate Monitoring Stations, organized Crop water budgeting exercises, developed context specific practices through pilots during 2016-10. Farmers were trained through FFS, Organic farming. Enhanced crop productivity, saved water and improved soil health. 2. NRM, Watersheds Developed 12 watersheds in Gadwal Tq. Executed plans. Improved yields of crops, milk, meat, farmers income. 3. Livelihoods Mapped resources, infrastructure and livelihoods in 16 villages, Achampet, TS. Prepared plans for improvement and executed activities. Observed significant improvement in people livelihoods. 4. Land and Water management Prepared status in Mbnr district, matched with existing technologies. Facilitated resources to manage. 5. Ground water Formed Water Management Committees at habitation, federated at Hydrological Unit. Capacitated to monitor, use water efficiently. Water users were trained on FFS, Farmer Water Schools in 16 villages, Mbnr district under APFAMGS Project supported by FAO. 6. Tank management Final Evaluation of KS-CBTMP during 2009. Stud conducted on lakes status in Hyderabad funded by HMDA. GoAP 7. River Basin Management CARE has prepared River Basin Profile. Prepared Integrated River Basin Plan for Wangchu River in Bhutan. Organized several meetings. Prepared report during 2008. 8. Irrigation management Water Users been organized into groups in 12 tanks, trained, facilitated to plan, execute. Executed in 12 tanks around Achampet Tq. In TS. 9. Child Labor Education Rescued child labor from seed production farms, provided residential education facilities, mainstreamed into residential schools, supported for continued education of about 1350 children in 15 years. RBC was visited by CM Sri N Chandrababu Naidu. CARE got awards thrice by District collector. Worked with identified Government schools in AP, TS, KS, Maharastra, Gujarat states. provided support in 6 years to improve attendance, children performance. Project funded by Monsanto company. 10. Urban slum development Solid waste management- Developed slum specific plans for 23 slums, funded by HMDA, Hyderabad. Executed social development activities in 18 slums. Contributed for Hussainsagar lake protection. 11. Vocational training Skill development- adolescent boys, girls were been trained on vocations and supported for practicing. 12. Women, Children, Tribal Formed SHGs, FPOs facilitated execution of programs in more than 100 villages. 13. Health Executed RCH program in Ija Mandal of Mbnr district. Organized women groups, health camps over 5 years. 14. Participatory Rural Appraisal About 250 participants trained on PRA. 15. Planning, Monitoring, Evaluation Studied- Assessments made about Impact of Agril., Horti. and Agri-business Interventions in APCBTMP, Submitted reports during 2015-16. 16. Preparation of Comprehensive Dist. Agriculture Dev Plans North Goa, South Goa, State Plan- Organized consultation workshops, prepared plans for 5 years period. Formed planning committees at village, block, district level in 2011-12. Project was financed by Director, DoA, Govt. Of Goa. 17. Preparation of Bio Diversity Registers Kadapa, Kurnool, Ananthapur, Chittur Districts. Formed BDG, trained, organized PRA, collected data, presented in Grama sabha, prepared bio diversity reports. 18. Evaluation study of Forest Development Agencies projects in Schendurney, Neyyar, Peppar Divisions in Kerala State National Afforestation Program, Finalized reports, submitted to CCF.

Name: Micro Enterprise Development Cooperative Society Ltd
Major_Activities1: The Micro Enterprises Development Co- Operative Society Ltd (M E D C S L) is a Community based organization of rural and urban slum women to promote household level micro-enterprises for sustainable livelihood of its members. The society came in to existence on 25-08-2009 and registered with the Deputy Registrar of Co- Operative Societies,Balasore Division of Odisha. The Mission Of MEDCL is "Sustainable Livelihood for Rural Youth & Women Through Promotion Of Micro-Enterprise in Rural Areas". The long Term Vision is to develop a viable and effective model so that the micro-credit is used by the women for productive purposes thus there is a visible change in rural economy. At present MEDCSL is functioning in 200 villages of three CD blocks of Balasore District i.e.Bahanaga ,remuna ,Balasore Sadar and 31 underprivileged slum areas of Balasore Municipality catering to the financial and livelihood need of 14,045women members. Over the years we have been supported by N A B A R D,P R Y O G,BASIX ,and Indian Gramin services (I G S)for various development projects and financial services in rural areas. During the last seven years the remarkable achievement of the cooperative society are as follows: (i) 1,316 women SHGs are formed in rural and urban slums of Balasore district involving 14,445 women members. (ii) 4,577 women S H G members are trained in S H G management and livelihood opportunities. (iii) Rupees three crore savings generated by the SHG members (iv) Rupees ten crore micro-credit loan was given to 10,000 women SHG members for farm based and non-farm income generation activities. (v) 4,000 nos of rural livelihood models demonstrated such as dairy , Goatary, Poultry,Fishery etc. for hands-in-learning and scaling up by women S H G members. (vi) Cooperative members were provided with social products such as water filter ,Solar Light ,smokeless chulla,sanitary napkins and health kits etc. MEDCSL has awell equipped office in Balasore Town. The office is fully furnished and Computerized with five 3rd Generation Computers,Printers,Scanner,Photo Copier and Broadband internet Connections. The total staff strength of MEDCSL as on 31st March 2016 is 42 of Which 27 (64.50%) are women.they are the grassroots Community level workers (Field Organizers)at the Villages /Ward and slums level who provide firsthand hand holding support to the women S H G members. Besides we have part-time experts on dairy,mushroom cultivation,food processing, woolen garments making and agarbati making who impart training to SHG members on specific trades.

Name: DADI HAMGIO CHARITABLE SOCIETY
Major_Activities1: To work for the overall Development of the society. To undertake project for self- employment such as horticulture and agriculture development. To shoulder responsibilities of relief and rehabilitation works and render voluntary services to the people especially during the of natural calamities/ epidemics and other emergencies. To maintain the highest possible standard of humanitarian service by running welfare institute like orphanage/ Orphan school/ old age homes/Vocational Institute/ Training centers/ health center/ welfare of woman/ widow/ Welfare of children/ woman adult Education/ Discourage of Child and Force marriage. To assist and undertake preventive and control measures in disaster prone zones and crisis management in disaster stricken localities. To promote eco-tourism. To encourage rainwater rainwater harvesting and promote use of non- conventional means of energy in remote areas especially solar. To established functional linkages with other reputed NGOs functioning at state, Region,Nation, And International Level. There shall not be any profit motive while carrying out the activities and achieving the objects of the society. the surplus fund/ assist, if shall be utilized only in furtherance of the object of the society. Promote entrepreneurship in both rural and urban areas. Working handloom and handicraft activities and rural areas. To cooperate, collaborate with center/state and other agencies to undertake development programmes in Rural and Urban Areas. Name: Commitment to Kashmir
Major_Activities1: Commitment to Kashmir (CtoK), a Registered Trust was started in 2011; inspired by the Late LC Jain, former Member Planning Commission, activist, economist, Gandhian, founder of the craft marketing movement in India and led by some of the premier individuals and organizations working in the Indian handicrafts industry such as Padma Shree Gulshan Nanda and Padma Shree Laila Tyabji with over 40 years of experience in the field. The objective of the CtoK Trust is to support and nurture a new generation of crafts persons from Kashmir, by helping them with contemporary design development, capacity building, technical support, procurement of raw materials, tools & equipment, one on one mentoring, professional entrepreneurship skills and marketing networks. Thereby providing the craft communities with a source of permanent employment, sustained earnings, opportunities and empowerment. The Commitment to Kashmir (CtoK) initiative seeks to address a dual objective of crafts revival and poverty alleviation in Kashmir by enabling positive transformation in the handicrafts linked economy in the state. It also seeks to reach out to the hitherto hidden part of the economy, women with the potential to be entrepreneurs and producers. The mandate of CtoK is to provide resources and skills to carefully chosen young Kashmiris with a design, management or craft background who have the talent and potential to become entrepreneurs in the field of traditional Kashmiri handicrafts, or those who are already established but need specific targeted financial inputs to grow and expand. The key drivers of the initiative are design, technical up skilling, one-on-one mentoring and marketing. The programs of CtoK have so far reached out to and benefitted 300 artisans through its unique Craft Enterprise Linked Livelihood Support Program to an initial group of 12 grantees all from traditional craft families in Kashmir. Their crafts range from felt wool rugs, Pashmina and Kaani weaving, Copper and Wicker, to Papier Mache mould making, Ari & Sozni embroidery, Tilla work, Crewel and Chain Stitch embroidery. Achievements of CtoK - 1. Increased employment. In 25% of the cases there has been more than a 100% increase in employment within the craft enterprise supported by CtoK 2. Boost the income level of the artisans. In 40% of the cases, the income levels has doubled. 3. Provide the artisans with a regular and timely source of income 4. Enabled the growth and expansion of production facilities (doubling of weaving looms set up) in the supported weaving enterprise 5. Developed new tools and equipment. Shabir Lone, a Kaani weaver supported by CtoK developed an innovative new portable and stackable loom 6. Expanded learning opportunities. Arifa a young Namda rug craftswoman was sponsored by CtoK to attend an International Felt Making Workshop in Kyrgyzstan 7. Develop a new and contemporary product range enabling artisans to have a competitive edge to the traditional craft skill in the domestic and international markets. 8. Marketing support through bazaars ensuring regular and sustained income to the artisans. 9. Restoring of societal confidence as well as economic well being

Name: Ophthalmic Mission Trust
Major_Activities1: About the Organization Drashti Netralaya is now a charitable organization founded by two eye care professionals with the intention to make the economically backward rural tribal area “Avoidable and Treatable blindness free” named Dahod at eastern border of Gujarat India since last 20 years. There are having backlog of 3,92,000eye surgeries in three districts they are working with. Drashti Netralaya is working in accordance with Government and they are working with district governance sharing common goals and strategies to eliminate avoidable blindness. Gujarat state government and NationalGovernment contribute financially, technically and in terms of human resources. Many individuals, national NGOs and International NGOs, as donorsare supporting this organization. Since 1991, 82% of work they are doing total free of cost to poor tribal people including all surgeries for eyes, more than 15000 surgeries a year. Drashti Netralaya has reached to Tertiary Eye care Center: As far as quality is concern their motto is single standard of care to all whether the person is rich or poor and hospital is Tertiary eye care center which deals with preventive and curative aspects all eye problems through various departments like Cataract dept, Retina and vitreous dept, pediatric ophthalmology dept, strabismus dept, ocular trauma care center, oculoplastydept, cornea dept, ocular oncology dept, optometry services, contact lens dept etc. They are having rehabilitation center for blinds and patients with low vision. Rural Eye health Care: People, with whom they are working, are illiterate. They were totally unaware about the eye care modalities when they started their service and now they are quite aware about eye care problems and treatment. These awareness they could achieve because of their intense outreach activities like Free Eye check upcamps and interior most village, fully equipped mobile ophthalmic units, School children eye screening programs for preventable blindness and door to door callof the patient to reach out the unreached. Education: To cater more and more patients and to expand their catchments they have many education courses like DNB Ophthalmology after MBBS, DO after MBBS., Post M S fellowships, NPCB training center for Govt doctors, Optometry schools and ophthalmic Technician and Nursing schools. Technical advancement:-Trusly Paperless System based Organization They have established complete eye care set up with advanced technology including paperless hospital with EMR and HMIS despite of being in rural remote area. Telemedicine center also is available to get highest quality and most advanced treatment to people of this area. Research: To avoid the blindness they are doing research including clinical and operational researches which are presented at national and international level through presentations and publications.

Name: INDIAN CENTRE FOR SPACE PHYSICS
Major_Activities1: 1. ICSP has achieved a unique distinction of becoming a SISTER ORGANIZATION of Calcutta University at par with Centrally funded organizations such as S.N. Bose Centre, Bose Institute, IACS, ISI, SINP, etc. in Kolkata region. 2. It has produced over 35 PhD students who received Degree from Calcutta and Jadavpur Universities. 3. It has participated in Major payload making projects and three of such payloads were flown to space by Russian satellite. 4. Its low cost Balloon borne program to do space based experiments at a height of 40 km is Internationally recognized. 5. Its has published hundreds of well cited papers in refereed journals. Three patents are pending. 6. State Government kept ICSP as a shortlisted Institutes of excellence who are funded with higher priority. 7. It has several permanent, semi- permanent and contractual staff members. 8. Its Midnapore campus (Ionospheric and Earthquake Research Centre) is being equipped with a 20" Optical Telescope, largest in the State and east India. 9. Its By-Pass campus, land of which was given by the State Government, is being built and the head quarter will be shifted there soon. 10. The payload X-ray Spectroscopy from Lunar Surface (XSLS) is being scheduled to be launched in 2017/2018 for science done from the Lunar Surface.

Name: The Blind Relief Association Delhi
Major_Activities1: Established in 1944 by Shri U.A. Basrurkar, a freedom fighter and automobile engineer and his wife Smt. Anusuya Basrurkar to offer sightless children a programme of education and vocational training. With a modest beginning in 1945 with 3 students receiving education and care at the Industrial Home and School for the Blind in a rented premises located in the rural Lal Kuan, Badarpur area on the outskirt of Delhi, the Association is today a leading institution providing direct care to nearly 300 blind children and adults receiving education and a wide range of vocational training in its campus located in New Delhi. Over the seven decades of its existence, the Association has taken pioneering initiatives in the field of education, sports, teacher training, vocational training and rehabilitation of the visually challenged. The Association received the Best Institution National Award for empowerment of persons with disabilities in 2012. Following is an overview of the Associations different services: EDUCATION: 1. J.P.M. Sr. Sec. School for the Blind (Estd 1967) is a leading government-aided residential school affiliated to Central Board of Secondary Education with over 200 children studying from Nursery to Class XII. 2. Unit for Children with Multiple Disabilities attached to JPM School takes care of special needs of VI children with mild mental retardation. 3. Training Centre for Teachers of the Visually Handicapped (1967-2007) 4. Durgabai Deshmukh College of Special Education (Visual Impairment) (estd.2005) affiliated to Delhi University offers B.Ed. Special Education (V.I.) 2-year programme. Total enrolment 55 teacher trainees 5. Computer Training Centre: Offers RCI approved 1-year Diploma in Computer Education (V.I.) since 2014 to prepare computer instructors for the blind - 25 trainees VOCATIONAL TRAINING: 1. General Mechanic cum Machine Operators Training Course This 1-year programme (Estd 1994) is recognized by Board of Technical Education, Delhi admits 20 trainees 2. Multi-skill Training Programme -20 trainees: 1-year programme for adult blind with marginally educated. Skills taught are: 1. book binding and paper craft; 2. basic massage; 3. chair caning; 4. candle making; 5. Packaging 6. Sewing and 7. Soap-making and cottage industries product. 3. Relaxation Massage Training (Estd 2003) - 10 trainees 4. Computer Training (Estd 1996) - 20 trainees 5. On The Job Call Centre Training (Estd 2008) - 10 trainees SERVICES: 1. Recording Studio to prepare audio recorded books and study material for the blind 2. Braille Production Unit 3. Placement Cell to provides job counseling and placement services to pass-out trainees, students 4. Orientation and Mobility and counseling for the newly blind 5. Hostel for Students and Trainees (300 inmates) 6. Health & Dental Care Unit 7. Library - JPM School and Durgabai Deshmukh College OTHERS: 1. Promotion of Sports for the blind – Establishment and support to Indian Blind Sports Association (Estd 1986). Co-hosted 20 National Sports Meets for the Blind since 1982.

Name: ARSHA DE TRUST
Major_Activities1: AIMS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE TRUST a. To educate the people of India in hygiene, health etc; and prevent young people from alcohol, drugs and immoral traffic etc; and for that purpose utilize visual media by producing and broadcasting T.V programmes, radio programmes etc; using modern information technology methods. b. To provide assistance or help to the poor, the needy, and the old. c. To give assistance for marriage of poor women. d. To give financial help for maintenance of houses for poor people and construction of houses for the homeless. e. To provide assistance financial or otherwise in whatever manner as it may deem fit for the Trust in case of flood, drought, earthquake, famine and other calamities. f. To rehabilitate people affected with AIDS, cancer and leprosy or give assistance for their rehabilitation. g. To institute centres for rehabilitation of mentally retarded and physically handicapped people. h. To run tailoring schools for helping the financially struggling men / women to help to find their own income i. To provide assistance both financially and consultant-wise support and involve in cattle stocks (live stocks, eg. Cow, sheep, chicken, etc.) Vocations. j. To start and run vocational training centres for young people to find their own income. k. To provide assistance and help to the physically and mentally sick. l. To provide assistance financially for farming and also to involve by giving financial and consultant support to the poor and the needy. m. To establish, and maintain Old Age Homes, Orphanages, Destitute Homes, etc to accommodate the ageing, suffering and other needy people. n. To establish, maintain and run studentships, scholarships and render other kind of aid to students including supply of books, stipends, medals and other incentives to study. o. To conduct camps, conferences, seminar workshops etc for propagation or imparting training in practicing any of the objects of the Trust. p. To disseminate the high values of life, through house visits, awareness conventions, counseling etc, and work against alcoholism, drug addiction, smoking, obscenity etc. q. To open and operate schools or other educational institutions to impart formal or non-formal education. r. To do any other objects of general public utility not involving any business, commerce or trade. s. To establish, develop, maintain and grant aid in cash or in kind to hostels, hospitals, medical schools, medical colleges, nursing institutions, dispensaries, maternities, child welfare centers and/ or such other similar charitable institutions in India for the benefit and use of general public. t. To initiate and implement rural development programmes and projects for the uplift of the poor, maintenance of drinking water projects in rural areas and urban slums, dwelling units and school buildings for the benefit of the economically weaker sections of the society. u. To provide monetary assistance to i) Deserving students whether they are directly under the care of the trust or not. ii) deserving children for medical purpose whether they are under the direct care of the trust or not iii) any destitute

Name: RANVIR RANANJAY DEGREE COLLEGE ASSOCIATION AMETHI
Major_Activities1: • The Society was found by Late Rajarshi Rananjay Sinh with the vision to enrich the society with knowledge and educate the farmers to impart the overcome the challenges in agriculture. • Society is running under its umbrella RRPG College situated in Amethi & Krishi Vigyan Kendra-II, situated in Sitapur U.P. • RRPG College comprises 9 post graduates departments spanning a vast range of subjects partnering to all branches of social science, arts, commerce and science. • The college having well furnished class rooms, equipped laboratories, rich digital library and extensive greenery. • RRPG College has 2 centers of distance learning namely IGNOU & UPRTOU. • The UGC funded, 3 study centers are successfully operating by college is i.e. Mahatma Ghandhi Study Centre, Indira Ghandhi Study Centre and Nehru Study Centre. • RRPG College is ‘A’ Grade Institution accredited by autonomous body NAAC (National Assessment and Accreditation Council) working under UGC, Ministry of Human Resource Development, Govt. of India, in 2013. • RRPG College has been recognized as “College with Potential for Excellence”. by UGC, Ministry of Human Resource Development, Govt. of India, in 2016. • Society actively participates/organizes Sports activities throughout the year. • Society organizes ‘Half Marathon’ to motivate rural youth by providing attractive prizes. • Society actively organized various social welfare works like Eye camps, Disable camps, Mass marriages etc. • RRPG College provides a wide range of facilities for sports and hobbies, has large play ground, a hi-tech auditorium, shooting range, well equipped indoor stadium, swimming pool etc. • RRPG college has NCC & NSS units working effectively and students are continuously participates in camps and competitions held at different part of country. • The college family consists of about 7000 students belonging to all streams of life, castes and religions and about 125 teachers and non-teaching staff. • Krishi Vigyan Kendra is a pilot project funded by ICAR, New Delhi is successfully running by Ranvir Rananjay Degree College Association from 2012 in district Sitapur U.P. for upliftment of farming community in 9 allocated blocks of the district. • KVK regularly conduct OFT, FLD, trainings and other extension activities as per need of farmers and district. • KVK have administrative building, farmer hostel, 35 acre instructional farm, fish pond, orchard and 6 demonstration units with technology park, Fodder & crop cafeteria. • In short span of time KVK developed vast linkages with ICAR institutes, SAU’s and other agencies involved in the same field and got popularity in between the farmers. • Till the end of 2016, KVK organized 14 OFT, 400 FLD, several training, distribute agricultural literature, distribute 700 qts. seed of grain, pulse, oil seed and sugarcane, 50,000 planting material, 190 qts wormi compost, 80 kg bio control agents etc. in between farmers. • KVK scientists and farmers are regularly honored by different agencies and societies. • KVK play a vital role in seed replacement, seed treatment, mechanization, soil testing, vaccination, post harvest management and promotion of entrepreneurship in between the rural youths.

It happens mostly on Mondays, being the first day after the weekly holiday. Many fake sickness to escape schooling, saying that they have stomach ache or head ache. Name: Arunachal Siksha Vikas samiti
Major_Activities1: Arunachal Shiksha Vikas Samiti Main Achievements The notable educational achievements of Arunachal Shiksha Vikas Samiti are as follows: 1. Providing qualitative nationalistic education through 16 nos of coeducational schools in 10 districts of Arunachal Pradesh. These schools are located in remote interior villages of Arunachal Pradesh with low access to quality education In these schools, activities for the integrated development of the five aspects (five koshas) of human personality through the five core areas of Sharirik (Physical), Yog, Sanskrit, Sangeet (Music) and Naitik –Adhyatmik (Moral & Spiritual ) Education are effectively carried out. 2. Running 9 (nine) numbers of Kasturba Gandhi Balika Vidyalayas (KGBVs) in 2 (two) districts of Siang and East Siang districts of Arunachal Pradesh. These schools are exclusively residential and free Schools for girls under SSA aimed universalisation of elementary education. These 9 KGBVs run by Arunachal Shiksha Vikas Samti have evolved to be the best and model schools among the government projects in Arunachal Pradesh because of its quality education program in the lines of Vidya Bharati as well as the vocational and specific skill development programs conducted in these schools. 3. Providing academic and allied support to 5 (five) nos of Associated Schools in 3 districts of Upper Subansiri, Changlang and Namsai. Though directly not managed by the Samiti, these schools also follow the quality educational programs (scholastic and co-scholastic) of Vidya Bharati and bring out qualitative outcomes. The local management bodies of these schools are getting expertise regarding school administration from the Arunachal Shiksha Vikas Samiti. 4. Regularly organizing teacher’s quality enhancement programs like Teachers’ Training, workshops, etc. Arunachal Shiksha Vikas Samiti conducts Teachers Training camps of 10 day duration with at least 50 – 60 teachers every year. Through these training camps, the Samiti imparts training to teachers in the areas of qualitative teaching learning methods, effective ways of evaluation, preparation of low cost/ no cost teaching aids, etc. More than 500 teachers have been effectively trained through these camps so far. 5. Annually organizing inter school sports, Science fests, literary and cultural competitions, Band Training, Personality Development camps, etc for students. In these separate events sports competitions like races, jumps (long jump & high jump), shot put and discus throw, games like kabaddi, volley ball, tug of war, archery etc are conducted and the hidden talents in those areas are traced and promoted. In the Science Fests under the Akhil Bharatiya Vigyan Mela scheme of Vidya Bharati, competitions among students are conducted at school level, cluster level and state level in the areas of science experimentation, exhibition, paper presentation, science quiz etc and the winners are awarded with prizes and promoted for higher level competitions. Similar efforts are being made through the Kala and Sanskritik Melas, etc in the respective fields. 6. Promotion of Girls Education has been one of the key areas of attention for the Vidya Bharati and Arunachal Shiksha Vikas Samiti as well. The Samiti has been following the Balika Shiksha karyakram of the Vidya Bharati in true spirit and organizing special programs like Balika Shivir (Girls’ Convention) Exhibition of Vocational and craft items prepared by girl students under the intervention of Balika Shiksha (Girls Education). Balika Sabhas and Matri Bharatis (Mothers’Councils) etc in the all schools. 7. Shiksha Setu: Identification of promising students with bright scholastic career for free education in Vidya Bharati schools outside the state. Nearly 50 students benefitted so far

Name: ISHAN PROMOTE ART CULTURE AND IMPROVE SOCIETY
Major_Activities1: Aims & Objectives The broad aims and objectives of ISHAN based on which it has been established, are: To achieve complete literacy and to work for promotion of education; To work towards elimination of practice of Child Labour and to take appropriate steps for their rehabilitation; To implement and co-ordinate various activities relating to welfare of people belonging to Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, Other Backward Classes and Minority groups and also engage itself in related research activities; To implement and co-ordinate various projects aimed towards development and maintenance of environment, plantations and all other projects/issues for dealing bio-diversities and also to carry out research activities. To work towards maintaining social harmony; To make efforts for the overall development of the Society; To promote moral and ethical values through social and educational institutions for inculcating self-discipline and developing an ideal National character; To implement a job-oriented and labour-based educational system; establish, manage and run such educational institutions for meeting the needs, aspirations and welfare of every section of society; To set-up and run Training Centres in remote rural areas of the State, to uplift the educational and economic standards of the deprived sections of society, and to eliminate their prevailing bad social customs, illiteracy, dowry system, child marriage, fanaticism etc.; To establish and run various Welfare Centres to promote de-addiction, welfare of senior citizens, physically and mentally handicapped persons and overall human development; To establish, manage and run high level Training Colleges to bring out personalities in the fields of science, education, literature and sports; To implement and research on projects relating to Panchayat & Social Welfare and Rural Development; To work on projects for animal husbandry; animal medical care and animal rights and to implement projects on development of fisheries; To work for resource-less and poor people by active involvement in rural development through public participation and to co-ordinate with social activities; To create awareness and implement various projects on Public Health and Family Welfare and to organize Awareness Movement for population control; To organize and conduct programmes on health, education and sanitation; create public awareness to control population and to prevent epidemics and to arrange for basic facilities; To work for conservation of soil and energy; To create public awareness about AIDS and other diseases and to work for preventive measures. Also to promote blood donations and organize camps for the same; To solicit and receive financial support from National and International organizations for welfare activities and to organize workshops/ programmes in backward rural areas as well as for women. Also to intensively work for consumer awareness and for protection of their respective rights; To promote cow protection and cow care and to intensively work for their protection; To carry out and implement, for the integrated development of the society, various schemes/projects in the fields of education, health, water conservation, irrigation, land reforms etc., securing due cooperation from time to time from the Administration; To make the rural women self-reliant by organizing their Self-Help Groups (SHGs) and to train and promote them; To implement various integrity based programmes to develop the leadership capacity of the society and inculcating the sense of belongings amongst people of all groups and religion; To work for the development of traditional agriculture and social forestry and to carry out various schemes to promote medicinal and aromatic plantations; To carry out various child development projects to provide opportunities for the proper development of children. Also to implement various schemes relating to family welfare, nutritious food, primary education, health, entertainment etc., for the intellectual, psychological and physical development of the children; To establish Libraries, Music Academy, Art Center and Gymnasium for promoting social and educational up-gradation. Publication papers and magazines on health and to work for the maintenance and protection of antique and archaeological collections of India. Also to establish, manage and run the educational and training institutions for promoting Sanskrit language and age-old knowledge system of India; To identify such historical, cultural and spiritual/religious places of ancient India, known as symbols of social integrity and to work for their protection and conservation and also to establish and manage cultural and spiritual institutions; To bring about social awareness and to take steps, with the cooperation of Administration as well as public, against corruption, injustice, atrocities and wrongful acts; To impart training to socially and economically backward communities, tribes, women and landless/small farmers, for the proper exploitation of natural resources and develop non-agriculture sources of income. Also to organize them into Small Saving Groups and to educate them for working together; To implement projects for development of rural sources of livelihood and to provide market for the sale of agricultural and other rural products; To manage, train and research on various schemes relating to watershed, participatory irrigation management, development of fallow land and integrated sanitation; To make every possible efforts to control/manage the situation arising out of natural calamities like flood, earthquake, draught, epidemic etc. and to provide necessary relief to the victims by securing financial and material support/assistance from other institutions, agencies and persons; To manage and implement all Governmental and non-governmental schemes meant for human welfare and to secure financial and other assistance from National and International agencies/organizations; To carry out various schemes for the development of handicraft and to arrange for necessary training and availability of techniques for artisans to make them self-reliant; To establish such Animal husbandry and agriculture based Cooperative Production Training Centres which are economically self-reliant and help the society for reducing the dependence on outside help (Governmental as well as non-governmental) for developmental works; To work for the social and economic development of rural areas in cooperation, apart from Government, with financial institutions like commercial banks, insurance companies and business houses of corporate sector; To arrange training programmes and develop necessary material for capacity building of government and non-government agencies and its employees and to monitor and evaluate various projects; To engage in all kinds of developmental work meant for the welfare of people living in urban slum areas;

Name: POONA BLIND MENS ASSOICATION
Major_Activities1: PBMA’S H. V. Desai Eye Hospital is a project of Poona Blind Men’s Association. It is a center committed to socio economic rehabilitation of blind since last 60 years. PBMA’S H. V. Desai Eye Hospital was established in year. So far we have examined 30.99 lacs cases and operated 4.38 lacs cases. Majority of these patients 60% are treated absolutely free and rest are charged nominal charges. It has always been our endeavor to ensure that we keep pace with advance in equipment and techniques so that we provide best service. These patients not only have good quality of vision but also have a gainful employment. a) Provide comprehensive quality eye care without discrimination, between free and payment Cases. b) Reach out program in the area up to 350 km from hospital. c) To provide free treatment to more than 60 % cases. d) To impart postgraduate and paramedical training. e) Research center to promote research projects. f) To develop super specialty services in Cornea, Vitreo Retina, Medical Retina, Glaucoma & Pediatric Ophthalmology, Oculoplasty and Low Vision. g) To develop Ocular Surface Management Institute h) To develop Community Ophthalmology Institute The hospital has the following facilities:  200 Indoor beds  10 Private rooms.  2 Private wards.  Private OPD for paying patients.  Separate OPDS for free and paying patients as well as specialty OPDS.  Medical Retina Units with double frequency Yag Laser, AB Scan, Fundus Camera (Digital) with FA facilities.  Glaucoma screening unit with automated perimeter and Heidelberg HRT 11  Community Ophthalmology Institute.  Strabismus & Pediatric Ophthalmology.  Cornea and EYE banking services  Oculoplasty service  Low Vision Clinic.  Pathology Lab services The hospital has expertise of performing topical (no injection, no pad, no suture) small incision surgery and Phaco surgery with non-foldable and foldable lens. We are also conducting squint correction, glaucoma surgery, pediatric cataract and oculoplasty surgeries including vitreoretina, keratoplasty. We also have facility to treat Diabetic Retinopathy & Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). We are also into rehabilitation of the blind, along with an old age home.

Name: Gram Jyoti
Major_Activities1: Gram Jyoti is dedicated to the development and empowerment of vulnerable groups and especially rural and oppress families through grass root action, research and awareness generation since 1998. It has rich experienced on project operation, management and its execution in sustainable agriculture, NRM, saving & credit, Water and Sanitation Development , child protection and women development program in Santhal Pargana region. Its’ credit has so many prestigious work in the area of water and sanitation program and awarded by the Honourable president of India under Nirmal Gram Purushkar, Jal Star award by the Danik Bhashkar print media on water conservation measure as well as local administration of Deoghar district on sanitation action. Apart from this, water aid india awarded to the Gram Jyoti as a best partners in east region of india. Core cut strategy of Gram Jyoti is Village level people institution like SHG/ Kissan Sabha/ Kissan Club/ VWSC to cater any development plan at ground level. • Ensured food security for 1200 Households throughout the year benefiting from social security and livelihood schemes and enhanced production in agriculture and allied sectors. • 55 acres of barren land was transferred for orchard development (Mango, Lemon, Guava, Jackfruit, Papaya, and Pomegranate) through which 100 farming families benefited. • 1 Lakh timber saplings distributed among 5000 families as part of family insurance • 52 nos. irrigation wells were constructed for promotion of irrigation. • 62 nos. of hand pumps installed and 189 H.P restoration done and community mobilized for its operation and maintenance. • Hand washing facilities constructed and in use with Force and Lift Pumps in 17 schools. • 12 families benefited through wormy compost production. • 138 Women SHGs formed and promoted • 70 Kisan Club formed and promoted • 26 Child Club (Bal Sansad) formed and promoted • 27 Adolescents groups formed and promoted • 6 water recharge tank has been constructed benefiting 272 tribal families. • 26 Roof top rain water preserver constructed in schools & community level for domestic use and water recharge • 204Village water and sanitation committees are functional at village level. • 49 villages have attained open defection free status. • 4855 families are accessing safe drinking water • 8564 low cost toilets are constructed of different model and are in use. • 25 PWDs friendly toilets have been constructed and 8 IHHL have been made PWDs friendly. • 83 school sanitary blocks have been constructed. • 3 information center at panchayat level are functioning • Training Module developed to impart training to the “Jal Sahiya” • 700 Jal Sahiyas trained in 3 district i.e Deoghar, Dumka, Pakur of Jharkhand state. • 469 masons have been trained with technical and practical knowledge on NBA toilet model and 56 master trainers have been trained with technical and practical knowledge on NBA toilet model. • Developed 2 model WASH park for demonstration of the rural people at Deoghar and Pakur District. • 2 Mini water supply scheme have been Installed at Chulhiya and Konkribank villages. • Nirmal Gram Panchayat Prushkar awarded to Thariyara & Postwari Pachayats of Mohanpur Block of Deoghar District.
