Name: GRAAMEEYA MAKKAL ABIVIRUDHI IYAKKAM
Major_Activities1: Graameeya Makkal Abivirudhi Iyakkam (GRAMEEYAM) having its Headquarters at D/No 6/72,Siruvani main road ALANDURAI P.O, Coimbatore -641101 and running 20-Bedded Hospitals, and Two Mobile Medical care Units have applied for grant-in-aid for the year 2010-2011. Their application for Grant-in-aid for their on-going schemes for the year 2010-2011 addressed to the Secretary to the Government of India, Ministry of Tribal Affairs has been submitted through this office on 01.07.2010 The institutions have been inspected and the notes of inspection is as follows: Graameeya Makkal Abivirudhi Iyakkam (GRAMEEYAM) is a registered organization rendering services mainly to the Primitive Tribal (Irular) Groups in the District in various fields like Health, Vocational Training like Tailoring, 20-Bedded Hospitals, and Two Mobile Medical care Units. The Grant-in-aid applied for by the Association for the year 2010-2011 is especially for the Health Services rendered by them. The audited accounts and Utilization certificate for the year 2009–2010 are enclosed herewith. Now, Graameeya Makkal Abivirudhi Iyakkam (GRAMEEYAM) has submitted proposals for the year 2010-2011 for release of grant of Rs. 73,14,318/- Activities: 20 -Bedded Hospital and Mobile Dispensaries OTHER PROGRAMMEESS OF 1. Vocational training for tribes Youth 2. SHG for tribes Women Though the association is involved in so many activities, they have applied for Grant-in-aid for maintenance of the Graameeya Makkal Abivirudhi Iyakkam (GRAMEEYAM) namely running the 20-Bedded Hospital and Mobile Dispensaries Units in Thondamuthur Block. 20-Bedded Hospital and Mobile Dispensaries All the above said schemes are functioning in the Thondamuthur block Coimbatore district. The Association is registered with Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India for receiving foreign contributions vide registration No.075850124. Annual returns in Form FC-3 were submitted to the Ministry of Home Affairs, New Delhi for the year 2009-2010. This hospital is located at Alandurai near tribal Settlement, which is 48 Kms away from Coimbatore Medical College Hospital. This hospital is well equipped with 20 Bedded Clinical Laboratory, ECG and in the scheme Mobile dispensaries is always visited about 30 tribal settlements.

Name: ICHAPUR SOCITY FOR THE WOMENS OWN IMAGE
Major_Activities1: 1. Running one nonformula school 40 in each at baidyabati areas in Hogghly district. Beside education education student are also provided nutritious food medical support and skill development training. 20of total stdent has been enrolled in nearby Govt. school every year. 2. ISWOI successfully trained 15 adolescent girl on beautician trade in which eight trained girls have already got job oppertunity at local perlors. Supported by ICDS cell Bhatpara municipality 3. The organization basically to ensure basic health education and other common rights at five different Brick kilns at Nilgange area of (N) 24 pgs. 4. ISWOI has completed a vocational training course on Knitting & Embroidery trade with 50 adiliscent girls in which 22 well trained have got employment oppertunity through this initiatives. 5. ISWOI time to time organized awareness camp on women & Child rights including Marraig rights & devorce Women exploitation & service Mechanism to prevent women harassement. 6. ISWOI actively involved to raise awareness on Climate change and impact of Golbal warming and protection of Natural Envioronment in collaboration with Ministry of forest Govt of India. 7. The organization time to time organized Awareness camps on different vital issues like HIV & AIDS pulse polio Immunisation consumer rights etc. 8. One charitable Homoeo clinic is running for local poor people by organization won initiative. 9. ISWOI was organized ten days awareness generation programme with perticipation of 30 women labour to ensure their basic rights and raise awarenees about different vital issues related to their daily life. 10. ISWOI generally coordinates yearly sports & cultural program where the local children youths encourage to perticipate in different sports event & cultural activities. 11. ISWOI is also running a computer training centre on Basic DTP F.A course with 200 student. Beside it organization also running a vocational training school on Wool Knitting trade with 35 local adiliscent to ensure Self reliant of the local Youths.

Name: VATSALYA
Major_Activities1: Our Organisation is able to create unique center for street children and orphaned and abondoned children in Jaipur. Our organisation has received award for the best performance in the areas of serving truckers population for HIV/AIDS through our clinic. We have so far rehabilitated over 500 children under long term care and equipped most of them with vocation trainings. We have also seen more than 6000 patients from the risk population of long ditance truck drivers. In addition to this we have initiated a campaign for fundamental right to health with our 22 NGO partners in the state and Jan-morcha at the state level. We have organised over 100 Health camps with average number of patient seen per health camp is 150, whic means that our health camp services have so cater the need of 15000 patients. We have established affective partnerships not only with grassroots level NGOs in Rajasthan but also regularly working with state government, central government, International NGOs and UN agencies apart from individual donors from country and outside India.

Name: Amiya Memorial Creative Art
Major_Activities1: We are socio cultural organisation engaged in various social awareness programmes besides cultural and intertaining presentation in pantomime. Wehave a good number of hearing-impaired artiste, whose economic establishment is also our one of the objectives. We have been working for the benifit of the society since the establishment of our organisation in 1995. We have been working to creat awareness amongst the people through Mime presentations, either single or in groups on education,girl traffiking, rural health, AIDS/HIV,Women empowerment, National conciousness, Environment etc,sometimes with our own and with the assistance of IEC Division, Health Deptt, Govt. of W.B and other NGOs. Our Director Secretary Sri Kalpataru Guha is a hearing impaired mime artiste. He received two times National Award in the year 1997(by Ministry of Welfare,Govt. of India) and in 1998(by Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment). He also received State Award(W.B Social Welfare Dept)as the best Self employed disabled artiste. Our Director also conducted Mime workshops in different status like Tripura, Assam, Nagaland, Arunachal pradesh, Sikkim, New Delhi, Hyderabad etc. on behalf of CCRT, New Delhi.

Name: Stage India Performing Arts and Research Centre
Major_Activities1: "Stage India Performing Arts and Research Centre" Stage India was officially created in 1998.Our mission is to create extraordinary theatre that inspires and entertain our audience and to provide outstanding theatre training and performances that educates and awakens the imaginations of our youth.Our theatre lab provides a form of experimentations by professional, the development of new performance material, and the rediscovery of classics.The lab enables artists to explore new work and new ways of working- inorder to forge a deeper connection between actor and audience,self and community. Stage Indias artists are encouraged to move theatre forward- to transform deepen and clarify new ways of working. we create professional quality theatre for a vibrant and diverse population.We encourage and improve artistic growth in the community by producing a broad reportoire theatre,giving local theatre artists creative oppertunities and offering educational theatre and outreach programmes. we are commited to creating, teaching and learning about theatre that enlightens as well as entertains, that explores the values and ideas of many cultures and earas,and that contributes the artistic and personal groth of both participents and audience.We work to create a learning environment that is a model for the collaborative work of theatre and life.We draw upon the talent of the actors ,directors, writers and designers from around the country who are shapping the Indian Theatre scene.Stage India also offers a wide variety of educational ,community and litterary programmes design to enrich and deepen theatre knoledge.

Name: Development Action Society
Major_Activities1: Development Action Society (DAS) is a woman based organization and is committed towards the development of marginalized women and children through education, health, protection and livelihoods. DAS was established in 1989 with the motto of “development of underprivileged women and children, regardless of their race, creed or religion; changing their world with the right kind of opportunities.” DAS initiated to support and strengthen the capacity of marginalized women and children in the sub-urban disadvantaged population of South and Southeast Kolkata from 1995 onwards. To fulfill our mission, DAS emphasizes on need-based interventions, serve as a resource for the field and enter partnership for funding to support priority-based projects. In the last eleven years DAS has made in-depth inroads in education, health, child protection and vocational training for sustainable transformation. Since 1995 our assistance has reached 4922 children in the age group of 3-18 years and has mainstreamed 3165 out of school children in the local govt. formal schools till 2011. Presently 1003 children are continuing in DAS run NFE centers, after school coaching support to 387 children’s, 109 children parliament representatives, 258 active children group members. DAS also covers 8074 patients for access to health services. DAS has also reached to 33 women with adult literacy programme. Moreover, DAS has formed and capacitated 95 women group members and 88 Child Protection Committee members. Apart from this DAS also celebrates:- “Annual Cultural Programme” – where children demonstrate their drastic performance based on their hidden potentialities through the event of dance, songs, dramas, rhymes, poems, puppet shows and many others. “International Child Rights Week (October 14-20)” – where children perform throughout the week based on awareness generation on Child Rights Issues. During the Child Rights Week children performed two plays on Child Rights, Child Trafficking and Right to Education and their street play in front of Silver Spring were also acknowledged for their efforts. “Children’s Day Celebration (14th October)” – where children play a huge role in Bal Utsav – an awareness generation initiative on Child Rights Issues organized by DAS, “World Health Day (April 7)” – an awareness generation initiative based on health & hygiene in schools and the area of intervention. Besides this DAS also promotes Health Camps are organized based on the Health cards and doctor’s Register. Owing to this 4 health camps are organized in a year, in reference to the prevalence of diseases in the health Register. Both women and children are attended through clinical services ensuring awareness of avoiding quacks in the pockets of non-availability of health facilities. 8074 patients have been attended through these clinics, 6 cases have been referred to Government hospitals. Community needful people sententiously attended health check-up camps according to their needs and ensured their improvised health seeking behaviors. Three types special health check-up camps are being conducted on Paediatric, Skin and Gynaecology; including general health check-up camps. We provided services to 638 patients (Male – 205 & Female – 433) in the year of 2010 through 21 clinics and along with 32 girls less than 6 years. In the year of 2011 up to November 2011, we have provided clinical services to 1640 and along with 67 Boy and 69 Girls less than 6 years. General disease trends in these four areas are Fever, cold & cough, gastrointestinal problems e.g. diarrhoea, dysentery, hookworm infestation, hyper acidity etc.; skin problems scabies, boils, pox, prickly hits, cut & sores, others skin infections; Gynaecological problems e.g. white discharge, menstrual discontinuation, sexually transmitted infection, soiling of groins etc. and major paediatric problems are diarrhoea, dysentery, hookworm infestation, low body weight against age, cold, cough and fever. DAS is working with the physical environmental issues like maintaining sanitation in the working areas. DAS’s focus is to stop open defecation in all the working areas to prohibit environmental hazards. The children of DAS run schools and coaching centers receives awareness on various environmental issues like importance of plantation, personal sanitation and hygiene. As a part of work towards keeping environment green and clean, World Environment Day is observed with various activities across all the centers and plantation is a common programme in it.

Name: DASTKARI HAAT SAMITI
Major_Activities1: The organization Dastkari Haat Samiti, is a national association of crafts people with members from all states of India. It functions independent of grants for its general activities and administrative work which come from contributions made by its members and basic infrastructural support provided by public spirited persons. Dilli Haat The Samiti conceived of and worked for the establishment of an innovative marketing infrastructure for traditional artisans known as Dilli Haat. It was set up in 1994 jointly by Delhi Tourism, the Ministry of Textiles and the New Delhi Municipal Corporation. This crafts marketplace is a contemporary interpretation of a traditional village market. Crafts Council of Sri Lanka and UNESCO have used the Dastkari Haat Samiti’s expertise to model Colombo Pola on the Dilli Haat Concept. Concept papers have been sought by Nepal and South Africa. Regular design assistance & Desigh projects across the country Bazaars across the country around 120 Dill Haat, New Delhi, Bombay, Pune, Hydreabad, Goa, Ahmedabad, Srinagar, Bangalore, Triputi, Indore, Gowhati, Cochin, Bhopal, Chennai, Kolkata, Lucknow International Events Dastkari Haat Samiti has done design development workshops with Pakistan, Vietnam, Srilanka, South Aftrica. Thailand, Nepal, South Asian Conturies. Given them trainings, skill developments, marketing stratergies Craft Maps of India 24 Craft Maps representing and describing each State of India have been created and Published by the Samiti at an estimated cost of 70 lakh Ruppes. The Map Exhibition was held at Dilli Haat 2005 inaugurated by President Abdul Kalam. It was then taken to the Frankfurt Book Fair. In India it was taken to Kalakshetra in Chennai and National Institute of Design, Ahemdabad. Half the Map exhibition was taken to Dilli Haat at Trafalgar Square in 2005 Dastkari Haat Samiti, flamboyantly integrated its artistic Craft Maps, Beautiful graphics in an exhibit to portray the boundless variety of Indian craft traditions. Finally the Maps were donated to Crafts Museum, New Delhi. Its value is approximately 70 lakhs. Art in Action in Oxford 2006 and 2007 Some of the major programmes to present our best before an international audience have been our collaborative ventures with Delhi Tourism to take Indian crafts and crafts people to Trafalgar Square, mounting a major exhibition of arts, crafts and textiles at the Frankfurt Book Fair. Art in Action fair held at Waterperry House near Oxford, UK. Our participation was a great success as India was highlighted in a major way for the first time, and has resulted in the Samiti being invited again in 2007. In 2007 Shabir Ali Beig won the “Best of the Best” prize UN Interpretations of the Eight Millennium Development Goals In collaboration with the United Nations in India,Dastkari Haat Samiti mobilized the creativity inherent in the Craft Sector to translate the eight MDGs into eight exclusive works of high artistic merit. The works representing skills in art, craft and textiles were commissioned for United Nations Day, 24th October, 2007 2011 May India Africa Summit 200 women craftswomen went to Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, 200 women craftswomen were invited to Addis Abba on the occasion of the India Africa Summit. The name of this historic exchange was coined Handcrafting Hope

Name: Samekit Mahila evam Bal Vikas Sansthan
Major_Activities1: SAMEKIT MAHILA EVAM BAL VIKAS SANSTHAN, Registered Office – A – 40, Brahmpuri, Faizabad Road, District Lucknow, in the State of Utter Pradesh . It is Registered under the provisions of Indian Societies Acts 1860, with the Registrar, Firm & Societies, U.P., Lucknow, having its Registration no. 1172 / 1990 – 91. The Area of Operation of the Society is the Geographical Area of the Country. The Society is a Voluntary Social Organization based on secular, democratic principles & works to promote Social Justice in the provision & distribution of various developmental activities for weaker section of Society along with other Social Welfare programs. Its activities are aimed at achieving the objective of Social & Economic movement through effective networking, lobbing, campaigning & public affairs related activities& also helping to create the atmosphere for promotion of National Programs in achieving the goal. Thus the main objectives of the Society are Welfare of Human Being, Educational & Socio – Economic Development of Weaker Section’s Youth (boys & girls). Aims & Objectives of the SANSTHAN have been details in Memorandum of Association. It is a full pledged unit & is running its own activities of Welfare & Development with the help of people’s participation & contribution / donation. The SANSTHAN collaborates with State & Centre on area of common concern, while supporting Infrastructure Development, Skill Development for Self Employment, Income Generating Program for women & youth , ( boys & girls ) Creating of Awareness for National programs & other developmental activities. During past year SANSTHAN had carried out several activities in the sector of skill development of unemployed youths ( boys and girls ) such as Vocational Training of Tailoring, Knitting & Embroidery, Secretarial Practice etc. Beside the organization of Income Generating Training Programs for Farmers, Vermi-compost Training Programme for Farmers & Unemployed Youths Improved Agricultural Practice, Soil Conservation & Reclamation of Land of new allotties of Gram Samaj lessee. Organization of Awareness Camps on National Programs such as Women & Child Health, Population Control, EDP camps, Aids, Pulse Polio, Tree Plantation, Environment Protection & Pollution Control, National Integration & Solidarity etc., have been arranged in the district Lucknow, Sitapur, Behraich, Balrampur, Gonda & Sultanpur. The Sansthan is running an Agriculture Awareness Programme in the Block – Hadhar Mau, in Gram Panchayat – Dudahi, also the Sansthan is trying to run a Rural Development Programme for the people of Dudahi, with the financial help of CAPART. In which the Sansthan will provide free of cost training to the farmers of all villages & also will provide Safe Drinking Water in all Seven Villages of Gram Panchayat – Dudahi. More over the Sansthan will provide Employment based Training to the Women / Girls of this Area, so they may become Self – Dependent. Also the Sansthan will provide Animals to the Unemployed Youths. The Sansthan is running A District Consumer Information Centre in District – Sultanpur, for which the Sansthan has applied to the Ministry of Food & Civil Supplies, Govt. of India to Appoint it as A Nodal Agency of Central Government. The Sansthan is working with the Animal Welfare Board of India. It is caring out its activities for the welfare of Animals in District – Lucknow, Sultanpur, Gonda, Sitapur & Bahraich. The Sansthan is running Veterinary Hospital cum Trauma Centre at Alijanj, Lucknow. The Sansthan is organizing Social Forestry Camps at District – Lucknow in Block – Gosaiganj, In District – Gonda at Block – Haldhar Mau ( West ) , in District – Bahraich at Block – Vishesharganj in last Three Years. Currently society is implementing Computer Training Programme in District - Sitapur with the financial assistance from the Schedule Caste Finance and Development Corporation, Uttar Pradesh Lucknow. Over the years the society has been very active in the fields of : a) Rural Development Programmes with the help of various Govt. Agencies. b) Women’s Welfare & Empowerment activities. c) Rehabilitation of Flood affected Families. d) Handicapped Welfare Activities. e) Social Forestry. f) Health Check – up Camps. g) AIDS Awareness Campaign h) Social Rehabilitation of S.C. / O.B.C.’s i) Stray Animal Welfare Programs. j) Social Welfare & Awareness For S.C. / S.T. / O.B.C.’s k) Rural Sanitation Programme l) Safe & Clean Drinking Water. m) Farmer’s Training Programme under Rashtriya Sam Vikas Yojana. n) Innovative Health Post A World Bank Funded Project. The society has been well appreciated and recognized by the public and authorities. The following projects have been executed by the society with the financial assistance from state govt./central govt. and on its own: a) Rural Development work at Dudahi, Haldharmau, Gonda. b) Rehabilitation work for flood affected families at Dudahi, Haldharmau, Gonda. c) Social Forestry Camps at Pratappur Upreher, Vishasharganj, Bahraich. d) Stray Animal’s treatment camps at Lucknow, Sultanpur & Sitapur. e) Employment based training for Women’s Empowerment at Lucknow. f) Handicapped Welfare activities at Ramkot, Sitapur. g) Social Rehabilitation Camps for S.C. / O.B.C.’s at Allahpur, Hazurpur, Bahraich. h) Rural Sanitation Programme in District – Siddharthnagar with the financial help from Department Of Panchayati Raj. i) Sampoorn Swachchata Abhiyaan in Block – Rampur – Mathura, district – Sitapur. j) Vermicompost Project under Rashtriya Sam Vikas Yojana in 8 Blocks of District Sitapur. k) Innovative Health Post at Birahimpur, Jarwal, Bahraich under U.P.H.S.D.P., A World Bank Project. l) Implementing Computer Training Program Financially supported from Anusuchit Jati Vitt Evam Vikas Nigam at Sitapur.

Name: ASSOCIATION FOR VOLUNTARY ACTION
Major_Activities1: Association for Voluntary Action (AVA) was conceptualized in the year First January 1980 as a non profit making voluntary Organisation and formally registered under Societies Registration Act XXI of 1860 in the year 1982 with the primary objective for socio-economic upliftment of rural poor and vulnerable section of the society. Latter on it was registered under Foreign Contribution Regulation Act 1976. Since then, it has been working tirelessly for the welfare of Older Persons, Person with Disabilities, Women and Children, and other deprived, marginalized and underprivileged sections of the society. During this long trek our Association carves out a name for itself as a leading Voluntary Organisation in the State. Presently our Association is providing both Institutional and Non Institutional services to the above said sections of the society. The brief summary of activities of the association is as follows. At-Dampur, Po-Berboi, Dist-Puri. 2 .At- Telendihi Po-Telendihi,Dist- Sundargarh. Name: SRUTHI KALA SAMSKARIKA PADANA KENDRAM
Major_Activities1: Around 500 Mentally retarded and physically handicapped persons where given proper training to come forward the main stream of the society. Trained round 9000 persons under various (Govt. and Non Govt) schemes and placed more than 5000. A day home for elderly persons is being run by our organization from 2010. We run a chreche under Rajeev Gandi National Creche Scheme for children of working mothers. Trained around 700 persons in arts and cultural activities during the last 5 years. Conducting awareness programme for AIDS awareness, Adolescent girls and youths. We have organized a training network spreaded over every district in Kerala. For providing quality training we have started ISET (Institution for Skill Extension Training) at the heart of the Karunagappally Town and Thevalakara Panchayath.

Name: North Eastern Society for Human Development
Major_Activities1: A society based on, Education for North eastern Youth, legitimate rights, equity, justice, honesty, social responsibility and a culture of service in which all are self-reliant. The new millennium has changed the prospective of North Eastern Society for Human Development like globalization and the Society started picking up different activities like vocational Training, weaving and cane training and Bamboo Crafts training. Thus as a journey with new globe, the Society had organized so many Social activity like Road Safety Programmed, National Science Day, Flood Relief, Health Camp, Environment Day, Handicraft Training etc. Various Govt. Departments cooperated to make this activity successful one and awareness on crop strong, protection were seen among the villagers. In search of right path many of our youths go to the other states and pay a handsome amount as a capitation fee. So we introduced the “Institute of Technology and Management “to save the capitation with the minimum fee. Vocational / Educational Training. The “Institute of Technology and Management Centre at Guwahati, supported by North eastern society for human development continued to recruit and train youth in various market oriented trades – Computer Hardware/Software, Electrical. A/C & Refrigeration, Dress Designing and Beauty Culture. 125 new admissions happened through out the year. Apart from the trainings, value additions through English Speaking classes, Life Skill Training, Updating of curriculum also happened through the year. For recruitments/admissions, large scale drives were undertaken around the neighborhood Government Schools, Residents Welfare Associations, Market Places as well as distant locations like Zoo Road Tiniali, Guwahati. Institute of Technology and Management centre running at other project locations-kokrajha, Chaygaon, Nalbari, Nagaon , Kharupetia and Jagirod have coached a large number of young adults and equipped them with crucial technical skills. The units are run on the Social Entrepreneurship Model. Instructors are recruited from the community and a nominal fee for services rendered is charged. NESHD believes that the concurrent development of preventive and promotive health is crucial to the well -being of those who are unable to afford regular health care. With this in mind, NESHD plays a crucial role in providing health-care facilities, developing health seeking behaviour and strengthening the existing health delivering mechanisms amongst the target communities August 2010, the Society Organized an Aids Awareness Programmed for rural artisans and organized a free health check up and medicine distribution camp for the local people where doctors from local PHC participated and examined the patients. Nearly 1000 people got benefited from the Camp.

Name: Youth Technical Training Society
Major_Activities1: OUR ACHIEVEMENTS 1. A handicapped person VINEET KHANNA who was tied to a stretcher created an organization to help the needy. 2. Hundreds of Youth were provided informal technical training trained during the turbulent 80’s in Punjab. They were absorbed as apprentices who were absorbed by the local industry. Thus providing them a new life away from violence and drugs. 3. Vineet was honoured with the Red and White Bravery Award and National Award for the Child Welfare. He was also awarded the Ashoka Foundation Award. 4. P H Vaishnav, an eminent social worker and retired bureaucrat put an end to the slight uncertainty in YTTS, by accepting the reigns of society as its president. 5. He converted the Society from being individual centric to a public society with approximately 100 members. 6. He improved the infrastructure of the centres from being under trees and tarpaulin to proper buildings. Many of these were leased from organizations. 7. A number of schools and organizations eg. YPS, Vivek School, St. Kabir joined in supporting our activities and adopted our centres. 8. With the launch of the Sarav Shiksa Abhiyan, which is very similar to Vineet’s Pustak, Then focused shifted from rudimentary exposure to literacy to higher levels of education like coaching upto class 12 of good but poor students in schools 9. Approximately 100 children were admitted to schools working another girls provided skills training in cooking, cutting and tailoring embroidery, beauty culture. 10. Computer training is given to the students. An elementary exposure to computer is given in our other centres also. 11. Our staff chief functionary and senior coordinator appointed as district adolescent resource trainer by Ministry to youth welfare and sports. 12. Mrs. Sangeeta Jund is appointed as Member of Juvenile Board by Chd. Administration. 13. YTTS forays into Haryana Morni Hills and Barwala 14. YTTS elects its new president Mr. K.R.Lakhan Pal on 3rd June 2009. 15. YTTS adopts Chunnikalan a village with a population of 5000 appox. In Fatehgarh Sahib in Punjab in devouring for all round development of the village. 16. The organization achieved a turnover of appox.40 lakhs.

Name: Kalras Education Trust
Major_Activities1: Provided high quality Education to all the sections of the society in general and poor and down trodden of the society in particular. Educated left out cases through adult education literacy mission and awareness programs. The programs run by this NGO are literacy campaign, environment awareness, adult education, computer program and literacy eradiation etc. Also provided free coaching to SC, OBC, ST and minorities to enable them to appear in competitive examination to succeed in obtaining a appropriate job in public/private sector. In the field of Agriculture organized many meeting convention of the farmers with the help of experts to aware them about the new methods of agriculture system. The NGO also organized many programs such as debates and seminars etc for the development of women and children In order to promote Art and Culture, Camps and Work shops organized with the help of experts in the field handicrafts. Programs organized with regard Art and Culture for dying Folk Art form for there revival and promotion also. Medicals camps, Pulse Polio, Campaign talks and seminars organized with the help of eminent doctors and health workers. More program are being organized by this NGO in this regard.

Name: Mission for welfare of tribal Child and Women
Major_Activities1: Our Vision A fuller human life for the poorest of poor Our Mission Help to develop human resource for marginalized. Information on MWTCW: Registration Details Sr. Type of Registration 1 Society [No.JJ-6696 dated 01/04/2003] 2 FCRA No- 063310066 3 12-A - awaited 4 80G - awaited MWTCW’s Registered Office: 1326, Forth Bridge, Napier Town Jabalpur Mobile No.9300119459, 9826144351 Email ID- clayton_arti@yahoo.co.in Branch Office: 386, G-3, Mohini River View, Sarvadharma, B-Sector, Bhopal (MP) Mobile No.9300119459, 9826144351 Our Bank: State Bank of India, Jabalpur (MP) UTI Bank Ltd. Jabalpur (MP) – for FCRA account Strategy MWTCW works through the intermediacy of NGOs development agencies, government functionaries, professionals and all persons who are concerned about the futures of rural people through the rural facilitators it trains. DETAILS OF ACTIVITIES DURING THE PERIOD 1 APRIL, 2009TO 31 MARCH 2010 Health and Hygiene Campaign: By organizing health and hygiene week, MWTCW spread the awareness in general public and especially in slum about the health and hygiene practices. What are the safe hygiene practices, why are they needed and what benefit one get, were told to them. The simple slogan “Health is Wealth” was made popular among the children. They were advised to cut their nails regularly and brush their teeth every morning were small but most important massages for them. The parents were advised to take care of their children by imbibing such normal but hygienic habits in them. World Environment Day MWTCW organized the World Environment Day and invited the Mayor and general people to take the part in it. The saplings of various varieties were distributed among people and they were encouraged to plant the saplings in their households and surrounding to support the environment. It was vary encouraging to note that a grand public support was received during the event. World Woman;s Day MWTCW organized ‘‘International Women’s Day on March 08, 2009 and appropriate messages were disseminated with the general public and school children so that they can understand the importance of the day Rural Sanitation program: MWTCW visited the nearby villages and organized the meetings with farmers groups. They were advised regarding personal hygiene and sanitation practices. The mothers were encouraged to keep the surrounding clean and insist the establish toilets in their houses. Program on Malaria Control: This year also we run a program on malaria control. We visited the same villages which we had been visited last year. We met the public and were satisfied to know that most of the people have taken our message serious and now use the mosquito net to prevent from bite of mosquitoes. Reproductive & Child Health Program: Once again to spread the awareness among the pregnant and lactating women, MWTCW organized the reproductive and child health awareness campaign. The women were advised to take IFA tablets, TT vaccine and also get immunized their children appropriately and on time. Awareness on environment: The meetings have been organized with the villager to encourage them to protect the environment. They were told not to cut the trees and also were encouraged to use organic fertilizers; vermin compost etc. to bring an in improvement in their fields. Computer trainings: For the benefit of tribal youths, MWTCW organized the computer training program in computer operation. They student ( both male and female) were taught about MS word, Excel, Access, power point etc. Nursery development: MWTCW encouraged the village to grow kitchen gardens. They were encouraged to plant the fruit trees and other saplings such as Amla, guava, papaya. This they can do even their courtyards or in their “angan” and even the female in the family can take care of them. This is also a good source of income as well as getting the health benefit by its consumption. Vocational training programs: MWTCW arranged the trainings for the child youth and encouraged them to take part in it. The girls were encouraged to join beauty culture and hair dressing classes to learn the skills. They were taught about the pedicure and manicure, various types of skin and its treatment, hairdressing styles etc. They were advised how to deal with the customer and were encouraged to get the proficiency in this field. Environment Protection & Plantation Program: On the occasion of Environment protection day (5th June) our organization MWTCW has been cultivated 500 plants in 50 different dry places where the planting was really found the project was funded by YMCA cantt. Jabalpur. Environment awareness Program: Program on environment Protection & awareness was organized in swarsati engineering college for engineering students in there campus by MWTCW in the month of august the project was funded by Sarda Shiksha Samiti Jabalpur.

Name: DRISHTI FOUNDATION TRUST
Major_Activities1: Our Mission: Providing quality of education, Awareness and health care in the spirit of the society, especially the poor, the disadvantaged and the disenfranchised irrespective of caste and creed. Our Vision: To identify and work with the impoverished, weaker and vulnerable sections of the society to find solutions to the challenges threatening their lives with the ultimate aim of establishing an aware, responsible and developed society based upon equality, fraternity and social justice, ensuring sustainable and holistic development with emphasis on human rights, and a culture of social service through creating synergy and building strategic partnership with the Government, NGOs (non-government organizations), SHGs (self help groups), CBOs (community based organizations) and various national and international organizations by planning appropriate downstream and upstream interventions. Core values: Humanitarian: We believe in the provision of humanitarian assistance to people wherever it is needed to relieve suffering and sickness. Professional: Our staff, members and partners are professional people committed to providing high quality training and expertise in disaster relief and rehabilitation. Impartial: We work with people regardless of race, religion or political affiliation. Inclusive: We believe that partnerships with individuals, other organisations and communities promote creative and fruitful initiatives. Impact: We believe that people in communities and aid agencies should be empowered to develop skills for immediate and future disaster response. Respect: We believe people affected by any social or medical can and should be empowered to contribute to relief, rehabilitation and development efforts.

Name: BOYS RECREATION CLUB
Major_Activities1: The responsibilities and duties of Democratic Government is well defined in their respective Constitution. But the performance of a State so far as constitutional obligations to their Citizens are far from satisfactory. One can not blame the failures of performances entirely on the Government shoulders alone. In this age of globalisation, Government is found to be overburdened despite their sincere desire and will to translate their ideas and responsibilities into action. There remain always a huge gap between the Government and the people so far as benefits of the welfare State to make them reachable to the just destination. Instances may be cited from the various fields of Governmental activities where Government can not serve properly according to the defined objectives of this State. As for example: Rural Sanitation, Health & Hygiene, Micro-financial benefits, Universal education, Womwn trafficking, Early marriage, Child abuse and many others. Without people’s active and meaningful participation, no Government can claim their success for the aforesaid programmes. Here comes the necessity of forming NGOs for implementation of Government programmess and constitutional obligation towards the citizen. A Nation can not achieve their goal entirely by the Government machineries alone. The gap between the shortcomings of the Government and welfare of the Nation should be narrowed to the desired end by the activities of NGOs. NGOs can play a very big and effective role to create a prosperous Nation by their sincere participation in various nation-building activities. Nation-building activities does not necessarily mean only physical welbeing of the people. The word,‘Nation Building’ include man-making activities too. Only a perfect man can do justice to the welbeing of the Nation. The NGOs should take allout attempts to link their activities with man-making mission positively without which the result of the Developmental programmes will bound to suffer. With each of the activities of NGOs, the true human approach should be linked up, if NGOs want to play a big and successful role to the nation-building activities to which our NGO, Boys’ Recreation Club, is engaged at present. The Boys’ Recreation Club started functioning in 1965 with the sole object of all round development of village, the detailed description of which has been embodied in the Club Constitution. The Boys’ Recreation Club is a registered Organisation under the Society Registration Act of the Government of West Bengal on 10th january, 1980 and also attain the Registration of Foreign Contribution (Regulation) Act, 1976 of the Ministry of Home Affairs under Government of India on 28th February, 2008. Since it’s formation, the Club started functioning and atpresent involved in several socio- economic activities which are not only limited within the village where the club building situated but is spread far and wide. Since it’s formation BRC has played a pivotal role in performing various social activities specially among the poor, distressed and the backward classes of the society like schedule Caste / schedule Tribes in Cooch Behar district. The organisation is engaged in performing humantarian services with an aim to extricate poverty and illiteracy from the poor, neglected and other deprived sections of the society and to provide various welfare measures for these people through multidimensional and socio-economic activities in order to improve and elevate their living standard. It has been a constant endeavour of some highly enthusiastic and light minded people to form a nonprofit making organisation to extend extensive services among the socially, backward and economically deprived section of the society. The organisation is committed to empower the people and facilitate the process of their self-reliance. The thrust of BRC on the issues are : I) all round development of village through socio-economic activities, ii) To build capacity, social responsisbility & to promote income generating programme. Iii) To empower rural people sicially and economically by upgrading their condition iv) Organising the unorganised people and stregthening the existing people’s Organization and Self Help Group. V) Promotion of grass root organisation. The activities in which the Club is at present engaged may be described under the following Heads at a glance:- 1) Rural sanitation Programme (UNICEF Project) 2) Total Sanitation Campaign (UNICEF Project) 3) Safe Drinking Water (UNICEF Project) 4) Water Testing laboratory (UNICEF Project) 5) Self Help Group (SHGs) (NABARD Project) 6) Micro Finance (Bank Project) 7) Youth Development Centre (NYK, Govt. of India) 8) Computer Tr. Centre (NYK, Govt. of India) 9) Gramin Yuba Utsab (Govt. India) 10) Public Library (Govt. of W.B.) 11) Disaster Management (Govt. of West Bengal) 12) Micro-Insurance (CNRI & LIC ) 13) Vocational Training ( NYK & Community Polytechnic Cell) 14) Ambulance Service (Public-private partnership, GTZ-KFW) 15) Social forestry (District & Local Administration) 16) Pulse Polio Immunization (District & Local Administration) 17) AIDS Awareness (District & Local Administration) 18) National Rural Employment Gurantee Programme (NREGP) 19) Low-cost Oxygen Service (Own Fund) 20) Homeopathy Charity (Own fund) 21) Student welfare (Own Fund) 22) Felicitation ceremony (Own Fund) 23) Women Day observation (Own Fund) 24) Children Park (Own Fund) 25) Publication of Annual Magazine & Sharad Sankha (Own Fund) 26) Construction of Community Hall & Auditorium (Own Fund) 27) Promotion of grass roots Organisation (Different Funding Agencies) 28) Construction of Ferro Cement water Filter (UNICEF Project) 30) Soil Testing Laboratory (proposed) (UNICEF Project) 29) Nursing Training School (proposed) (Public-private partnership, Health Dept. Govt. of W.B.) Special Distinction & Impact. As a result of our activities, Socio-economic condition of our area of operation (4 Block) has undergone sea of changes especially the upliftment of women folk is noticable. In the field of Rural Health, Sanitation programme undertaken by our organisation is benefited much especially the water-borne diseases has declined to a greater extent. The Water Testing Laboratory of our organisation has started functioning which has great impact for eradication of Water-borne diseases. In this connection, mention may be made about Six Nirmal Gram which has been declared by the Health department, Govt. of India. This was possible for the active participation of our organisation in the Total Sanitation campaign. We have achieved a special place of honour in this State as a result of successful implementation of the activities mentioned earlier. We have received the State Level Outstanding Youth Club Award by Nehru Yuba Kendra, West Bengal Zone, Kolkata for the year 2001-2002 in recognition of our outstanding services in the field of welfare. We have received and still receiving funds from state level funding agencies as well as central Level funding agencies and other sources.

Name: NIRAMAY PUNE
Major_Activities1: 1) CHILD HEALTH CARD SCHEME(CHCS) i.e. IMMUNIZATION PROGRAM: To provide free immunization to the children of the age 0 to 6 and would be mothers. Also to provide awareness about health and hygiene. Infrastructure & staff: We have two well equipped dispensaries along with a team of medical officers, medical assistants. Each mobile dispensary has a fixed schedule of slum visit for 5 weeks. The schedule is attached with the document. Monitoring: There is one medical officer as a in charge of the mobile dispensary. He / she is responsible for all the operations on the mobile van. Reporting: Monthly report of all these three projects is reported to all the donors and the members of the board of trustees as well as to Pune Municipal Corporation. Till date could register 35000 children 2) KISHORI SHAKTI PROJECT Initially we have started this program in 7 slums. In which we are running daily classes for our beneficiaries i.e. adolescent girls. We are focusing on life skills training programs such as self awareness, body language, self presentation, interpersonal relationship, assertiveness, coping with emotions, empathy, problem solving, goal setting and decision making, creative thinking, critical thinking etc. Introduction to sensitive topics like HIV, birth control techniques etc are being introduced at appropriate stage. Also conducts introductory program to inform about the legal provision for crime related to women. Now the same program is conducted in 9 slums in Pune Municipal Corporation area. 3) HEALTH AWARENESS PROGRAM and TRAINING OF ANGANWADI WORKERS Since last four years Niramay is conducting free immunization program for children of the age 0 to 6 years in the slums of Pune Municipal corporation area. While conducting the activity, our team noticed some of the most common things about health and hygiene in all these community. We used to conduct the immunization activity with the help of Anganwadi workers of ICDS. The supervisors and the CDPOs of these ICDS projects requested Niramay to conduct health awareness activity in these slums and also to conduct training of Anganwadi workers on health related topics. Initially Niramay conducted awareness activity on topics like nutritious diet, awareness about need and benefits of proper breast feeding, how to prevent rainy season diseases, water borne diseases, viral, contagious, diseases related with the reproductive organs, disease related with the various addiction , HIV AIDS, health problem related with women and girl child, swine flu etc. The team on two mobile dispensaries used to counsel the parents on various health related problems. 1. Impact of our work has created 1) Vaccination(CHCS): Till date we have reached more than 30000 children and in a year we would definitely reach more than 40000 children in a span of a year. Conducting the program in 135 slums and 21 construction site. 2) Kishori Shakti Project: Initially started the program in seven slums from Pune city. Now reaching to 10 slums from Pune Municipal corporation area. Daily classes are conducted to train the adolescent girls about life skills. In each slums average 30 adolescent girls attend the classes and in some occasions more than 100 girls from each slums participate in the activities. Now parents initiative is increasing and more & more girls are joining this Kishori Shakti Movement.

Name: ITCON SKILL DEVELOPMENT FOUNDATION
Major_Activities1: ITCon Skill Development Foundation is an ISO 9001:2008 certified premier skill development Organization, recognized by the Central Govt. as authorized training partner under the NSDC Star scheme, with over 30 years of experience in providing high quality Education and vocational training of the unemployed youth necessary to upgrade the lifestyle of the trainees and enhance the employment opportunities for them. We committed to provide high quality Education and Vocational Training to bridge the gap between demand and supply of skilled manpower across the state. We undergo several survey and skill mapping exercises to identify the possible gaps and henceforth provide the vocational skills necessary to upgrade / prepare the students in lieu with the prevalent Job opportunities and hence a source of livelihood. We are also committed to developing the vocational skill by deploying a team of associates, trainers, faculty members and well equipped high quality skills development centers. ITCon focuses on the employment opportunities of our students in both the organized and unorganized sector. As ITcon has been awarded the recognition to train the trainees under the NSDC Star scheme, Forest Department, Madhya Pradesh Govt. it is more focused and committed towards the conduction of High quality training adhering to the NSDC skill norms to provide exceptional and most skillful training to the youth focusing on the career opportunities, high standard of living and a disciplined lifestyle to follow.

Name: Sukchar Pancham Repertory Theatre
Major_Activities1: SUKCHAR PANCHAM REPERTORY THEATRE AT A GLANCE Regarding our Name ‘Sukchar’ is the name of the Calcutta suburb whose life and business form the cornerstone of our theatre. We feel that this is the first thing we need to say about ourselves. ‘Pancham’, which is ‘fifth’ in English, refers primarily to what is often called the ‘fifth veda’ – the theory of drama by the sage, Bharata. We aim to rediscover the classical and folk roots of Indian theatre. The five fingers on a hand are not all of the same length, but this variety can be a source of strength. Whether we are five or five hundred, here the big and the little come together and work together- the basis of our strength and well-being. This is what Tagore thinks about the number five, as he describes his hero Amit in the novel Shesher Kobita: ‘There is something special in his appearance – he isn’t just any one of a group of five, he is rather absolutely the fifth, and attracts the greatest attention, to the detriment of others.’ Pa, the fifth note of the octave, is almost indispensable in all forms of Indian music. We dream about and work towards a future when any discussion of Indian theatre shall find us a small but indispensable part of its history. Regarding our Work Staging sixty-odd plays in twenty three years ourselves, we also organise Chhotoder Natoker Ekdin Pratidin, -One day theatre in education workshop for students. Over a period of twenty three years, we have worked with students from about hundred institutes ranging from primary schools to graduate colleges to help them to act, put them on stage, enrolled them in drama clubs. The regular Creativity & Personality Development Workshop in schools is named as Srishtisukh. To encourage them further, we have organised inter-school drama competitions, under a programme named Tiner Talowar. Organized Shishutirtha - seven days summer camp for students & Bado Hawa Khub Bhul - an open forum with child-psychologists and guardians for a healthy generation. We have been helping the challenged persons in behavioral therapy through theatre at a home called Anandolok. Besides, we’ve experience to work in a long phase with the lifers for their rehabilitation at Dum Dum Central Correctional Home. We have brought together rural folk artists and street drama groups in our Folk Culture Festivals. For twenty straight years, we have been putting on the annual Darshaker Darbar, a unique drama festival in Bengali where the director must face the audience after the show and answer their questions. There is even a prize for one who asks the best question. We have prepared and produced plays on topical subjects, for the specific needs of social work organizations ranging from education to environment, health issues to psychology, women’s problems to child labor & the same for commercial organizations as well. We have produced a bunch of professional theatre artists, put up a unique stage for theatre-on-demand, put together an essential collection of audio cassettes, compact discs, projector slides, movies, books and magazines, published two well-received and critically acclaimed books, established a forum for the discussion and practice of modern, scientific techniques of theatre. We have carved out a free area for children – Tapoban, to learn about the environment and contemplate about their learning. It offers free-form education for children, and aims to supplement the school curriculum with allied arts. Under the Parichay programme, we look for new talents who show promise in these fields. Our success is evident in the fact that those who represent the teaching and driving force of our group today were once recruited here as trainees.

Name: Karnatak Lingayat Education Society
Major_Activities1: On the 13th of November, 1916 a pioneering effort began that changed the educational landscape of North Karnataka. This was the day the first institution of the KLE Society was established. From humble beginnings rooted in the sacrifice of its founders, the Society now runs over 254 institutions across Karnataka, parts of Maharashtra ranging from kindergarten to post-doctoral research. The underlying philosophy being to encourage individual learning that would transform society. Currently over 1.25,000 students are pursuing their academic dreams in these institutions that impart quality education in areas ranging from School Education Collegiate, Doctoral and Post-doctoral studies in Health Sciences, Agriculture, Engineering, IT, Law, Pharmacy, Nursing, and Management to conventional education in Arts, Science & Commerce. They are inspired by over 16000 accomplished and highly qualified faculty. The UGC accorded Deemed University status to KLE Society’s J N Medical College, Belagavi and other health science institutions in recognition of the excellent academic standards. The KLE University established in 2006 with eight constituent colleges in the disciplines of Medicine, Dentistry, Nursing, Pharmacy, Physiotherapy and Ayurveda has been reaccredited at the “A” level by NAAC for second cycle of five years in 2016. The KLE University’s Research Foundation has forged successful collaborations and alliances with 6 National, 14 International Agencies and 19 International Universities from USA, Canada, UK, Europe and South Africa, prominent among them being World Health Organization, National Institutes of Health, USA and Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation. In the health sciences domain KLE has signed an MOU with University Sains Malaysia,Penang, to run USM-KLE International Medical Program. Running for past six years at Belagavi currently it has around 500 students on its rolls. KLE Technological University established at Hubballi in 2015 is partnering the “Make in India”. The KLE Society’s successful foray into healthcare began with the 2400 beds Dr. Prabhakar Kore Super Speciality Hospital and Research Centre at Belagavi and has now expanded to 4000+ beds medical facilities especially for rural masses. This includes 500 beds Centenary Charitable Hospital, 200 Beds Cancer Hospital 300 Beds Ayurved Hospital, 1700 charitable beds, 60 beds ICU at Chikodi and Rural & urban Primary Health Centres under PPP scheme of Govt. of Karnataka. KLE is the largest private contributor in the region. The health institutions also conduct Free Health Camps across Karnataka and South Maharashtra. Welfare of the farming community is central to the “KLE vision”. Besides providing educational opportunities to the farming folk KLE also equips farmers for innovative farming practices and adoption of technology through activities of the KLE Krishi Vigyan Kendra, Mattikopp, Belagavi. “Swashakti” the women empowerment cell of KLE University and Family Counselling Centre at Ankola provide vital interventions for the benefit of society at large. KLE ‘VenuDhwani-90.4 FM’ Belagavi and KLE Dhwani 90.4 FM Hubballi play vital role in disseminating information on health, education and local folklore and culture. Having completed 100 years of service to society, the organization has been instrumental in transforming the educational and healthcare landscape in the region and beyond.

Name: Bhoj Shodh Samiti
Major_Activities1: The BHOJ SHODH SANSTHAN aims at following eight fold activities - 1. BHOJ SHODH SANSTHAN conducts social and literary activities non political and without any distinction. 2.Conservation of literature, folk art, music and culture. 3.Conservation of old literature historical monuments and articles of maharaja BHOJ period . 4. Organization and conduction of seminars, literary, folk music and artistic programs. 5.To have in depth social approach, encouragement of achiever women, boys, girls and youths for their out standing achievement and also to train them. 6.To act as a bridge between the established and new comer writers and poets and to provide proper stage and occasion for their creation. 7.Extension of benefits of research and scientific innovations and inventions to the mass, in the fields of education, health and environment. 8.To establish library and museum to encourage educational activities. the achievements of BHOJ SHODH SANSTHAN The BHOJ SHODH SANSTHAN has established a library with out any aid by government which contains 1400 books pertaining to social, culture, history and literature. The library is enriched with 17 rare books collected from different sources. The organization has its own computer, laptop, printer, film projector and sound system which are essential for its activities . The organization has so for displayed many art exhibitions. Apart from collection and conservation of BHOJ literature to provide a stage to poet and writers of MALWA and NIMAR regions of Madhya Pradesh. The organization is benefited with publishing of an annual magazine named YASHDHARA since 2007 . Last year the sixth issue was published successfully. As regard literary activities KAVI GOSHTHI, SHODH SANGOSHTHI, Seminars and MAHILA SAMMAN are conducted from time to time with wide publicity. Free film shows in schools and other institutions by this organization have been appreciated by all concerned. Even citizens and senior officers of the district have given a grace by their presence in these programs. Cine Vision is one of the most popular and positive activity of the organization which aims to unite the people with positive aspect of the films. On first Saturday of every month some rare but standard films are shown witch are viewed by 50 to 55 family members. In addition to this organization has stepped in the field of film making by making short named film MARYADA named for SAMARG SWACHHTA Mission’ of M.P. Govt. The organization has also organized BHOJ MAHOTTASAV for two continuously years in collaboration with KALIDAS SANSKRAT Academy and Dramas JANYODDHA with SWARAJ SANSTHAN SANSKRTI VIBHAG of M.P. Govt. for last three years. The organization also co operates and takes active part in workshops on up lift of backward classes conducted by SAHITYA Academy . The library of the organization also gives opportunities to writers , readers and research scholars by providing books and consultation free of charge. This has helped the research scholars to participate at the state level seminars successfully thus the organization encourages and helps the writers even to get there written matter published. BHOJ SHODH SANSTHAN has been registered by Registrar Societies Indore with registration no. 03/28/01/12475/10 dated 4 FEB 2010. The organization has a bank account with state bank of INDIA, branch DHAR in the name BHOJ SHODH SANSTHAN /Editor YASHDHARA . account no is 63033568636. Organization has also INCOME TEX PERMANENT ACCOUNT NUMBER AABAB6598G . The organization consists of five member of staff headed by Dr. DEEPENDRA SHARMA who is a well known scholar of social science.

Name: SUPREME TASK
Major_Activities1: Supreme Task is an NGO working towards community development in 18 States of India since 1993. Our goal is to focus on Education and Health as well as social, moral and spiritual well being of people. Not only that, it helps young men and women to explore their talents and use it for the interest of our nation. Most important programs run by Supreme Task are leadership development, equipping and training youth of India, Child Development, Health services and awareness, Education to all and disaster mitigation. We are also working in one of the poorest District (Balangir) of Orissa under KBK districts announced by Govt. of India. Out of various needs of the people of Balangir District, Health is an emerging need owing to lack of medical/health facilities compiled with decreasing health status of people. Drought, less industrialization, unemployment, migration, etc. contributes to the poor health status of people in different Blocks. One 150 bedded Hospital in District headquarter and 13 other Primary Health Centers, which are not properly equipped in terms of manpower and equipment found to be inadequate in meeting the health need of 13,35,760 people of this District. Based on the need, we have taken over an existing Eye Hospital and converted it to 50 bedded General Hospital in Balangir district headquarter. We have a plan to equip this hospital with all latest medical equipments, sufficient manpower and better service facility for the people of this area.

Name: Bookaroo Trust
Major_Activities1: Twenty one editions begining November 2008. In 2017 we plan to reach 10 cities. Reached out to 25000 children in main festival and 16000 in outreach programme in 2016. OUtreach programme went to 175 schools which were a mix of language, underserved, government and private schools. The cities we go to are Delhi Srinagar Pune Kuching Malaysia Goa Ahmedabad Jaipur and Kolkata. Also conducted a storytelling workshop for over 100 librarians and teachers, called Kathakar. Programme sessions in Bookaroo have included Dramatised reading, Theatre, Non-stop storytelling for younger children, Storytelling through puppet shows, Informal book launches by Indian authors, Craft activities, Comic making, Art and illustration workshops such as folk art, A doodle wall (a temporary installation where illustrators will create a panoramic picture with children), Environment-related workshops, Nature walks, Panel discussions with authors and children, Creative writing workshops, Poetry sessions, Sessions on the life and times of great Indians, Exhibition of illustrations from children’s books. There have been enquiries for us to hold Bookaroo in south and south east Asia.

Name: GOBARDANGA NAKSHA
Major_Activities1: THEATRE RESEARCH & DEVELOPMENT: Performance(120 shows in a year), Different type of Seminars & Workshops, Children workshop – School Children, Slum Children & Child Labor, Deaf & Dumb, Blind Children, Tribal, SC & ST Children, In search of Children Theatre, Capacity Building Workshops, National Theatre Festival, Natya Utsav, Inter School Theatre Festival, Folk Festival, Computer Training, In-House Theatre Training, Celebration in World Environment Day, Sachha Bharat Avijan, Children Day, World Women Day, World Theatre Day, Group Foundation Day, Kabi Pronam, Awareness of Consumer Right. Debu Memorial Award: as GURU PRONAM to MR. RUDRAPRASAD SENGUPTA; PADMASHREE NIRANJAN GOSWAMI & MR. SURESH DUTTA, MR. BIBHAS CHAKRABORTY; MR. CHANDAN SEN; IN 1016 MR. MANOJ MITRA. ACHIEVMENTS: Last 35 years, GOBARDANGA NAKSHA produced 45 productions. Apart from all those productions NAKSHA also produced Workshop based productions in which children and students took participations in 40 plays and 2 Puppet plays. In the journey of NAKSHA during last 35 years also produced 7 Mime performances. Some of notable productions are KHARIR GONDI(Telecasted on DD Bangla, Doordarshan Kendra, Kolkata), ATHA SIKSHA BICHITRA(Telecasted on ATN Bangla), DAKGHAR, TIN PAISER PALA, YADI AR EKBAR, EKHONO, JION PALA, SHANI, ATMAJA, LEBEDEFF, MAHANAGAR, GHORAR DIMER GAPPO, SWAPNA SWADESH, RAJAR ASHUKH, RANGE BANGE RABI, BILASIBALA, CHELETA, SUVA, ICHHAPURAN, GHARE BAIRE, BINODINI: A WOMAN A HUMAN, TIRANDAJ DAMON, THOLI BURIR GAPPO, GOBARGANESH etc. AWARD: In 2003 ATMAJA awarded by PASCHIMBANGA NATYA AKADEMI, Dept. of Information & Cultural Affairs, GOVT. OF WEST BENGAL as BEST PRODUCTION OF THE YEAR. In 2003 UTTAM MUKHOPADHYAY SMARAK SAMMAN by MEGHOOT NATYA SANASTHA, KOLKATA for TOTAL THEATRE ACTIVITIES. In 2005 SHYAMAL SEN SMRITI SAMMAN by SWAPNASANDHANI, KOLKATA for TOTAL THEATRE ACTIVITIES. In 2009 BIJON BHATTACHARYA SMRITI PUROSKAR for production KHARIR GONDI by BENGAL SHRACHI GROUP, KOLKATA. In 2012 GOUTAM ROYCHOWDHURY MEMORIAL AWARD by BAHARAMPUR RITWIK for TOTAL THEATRE ACTIVITIES. In 2011 BADAL SARKAR MEMORIAL AWARD for production BILASIBALA by NATYAPANJIKA, KOLKATA. Our Founder President & Director of NAKSHA MR. ASHIS DAS is a SENIOR FELLOWSHIP AWARDEE by the MINISTRY OF CULTURE, GOVT. OF INDIA in the field of THEATRE for the year 2008-2009. BEST DIRECTOR AWARD BY MUNAS, KOLKATA. SOVON PUROSKAR by MADHYAMGRAM AVIJATRI. TATHAGATA MEMORIAL AWARD by BARASAT BIKSHAN. Our Secretary and senior Actress of NAKSHA MS. DIPANWITA BANIK DAS is a SENIOR FELLOWSHIP AWARDEE by the MINISTRY OF CULTURE, GOVT. OF INDIA in the field of THEATRE for the year 2013-2014. Our student MS. LINA DAS got CCRT scholarship last year. MS. BHUMISUTA DAS also got young artist scholarship from MINISTRY OF CULTURE, GOVT OF INDIA IN 2016. She also got Debabrata Chakraborty Memorial Award in 2014 by Radhanagar Darpan, Kolkata. In 2015 she got Biswadev Dutta Memorial MEDHA PUROSKAR; IN 2013 She got best actress (‘Binodini: a woman a human’) award from Natyapanjika, Kolkata. She also goes to South Korea for 28 days residential theatre workshop. IN 2015 WE ARE BUILD UP A EXPERIMENTAL SPACE (30’X40’X22’) CALLED GOBARDANGA SANSKRITI KENDRA. It was inaugurated by Honourable Minister MR. BRATYA BASU on last 3rd October,2015.

Name: Mission Anugrah Organization
Major_Activities1: 1. Going among the common people and making them aware of education, health and basic needs. 2. Wherever there are people belonging to backward caste, providing them access to education moreover providing them primary medical care. 3. Helping poor children, orphan children and destitute women in regards of education facilities and health facilities. Opening schools, orphanages and hospitals where there is requirement. Providing free tuition and acquaint them with moral education. 4. Helping people who fall prey into exploitation. Working for the growth of humanity. Giving them legal, financial and medical support. 5. Working in the area where it is nearly impossible to find the Government support. Reaching out to the lowest and the commonest people with the every project of the Government and working for their rights. 6. Providing greater awareness of health and education problems, and finding means to solve them in and with the communities. Giving consideration to people who are mentally challenged and also to those who suffer from mental disorder. 7. Mobilizing women in small viable groups. Providing them training and access to credit, training for skill upgrading. Enabling groups of women to take up employment cum income generation programmes by providing backward and forward linkage. 8. Providing aid and support to the deserving and/or socially or physically handicapped individuals, hearing impaired and mute children wherever and whenever possible, with training, or giving them financial aid. Opening special schools for mentally or physically challenged children. Distribution, purchase and fitting of aids and appliances. 9. Telling people about the good deeds of Jesus Christ:- I. Conducting various programs like community development projects and building church fellowship communities. II. Establishing youth committees and motivating them to become good citizens of the society. 10. Organizing medical camps for vaccination and awareness. 11. Working for the rights of women and children. 12. Arranging for supply of safe drinking water and basic sanitation facilities, provisions of affordable technological tools, and concentration on building health infrastructure. Researching in to the alternate methods of health care deliveries and low cost health technologies. 13. Fighting against exploitation, injustice and corruption if found against any individual, class or community in the society. 14. Educating people for adoption of the good norms of citizenship and helping them to inculcate the ideals of national unity. 15. Borrwing funds /finance/loans banks or other leding institution. 16. Providing free legal advice to the poor and destitute people. 17. Creating awareness among the people regarding AIDS and other fatal diseases. 18. Educating people against the consumption of drugs and alcohol.

Name: Helath Action by People
Major_Activities1: The principal achievements of Health Action by People (HAP) are detailed below 1. Tobacco control HAP has been the pioneer in Tobacco control activities in Kerala. Our principal accomplishments in this field are (a) Influencing the government to insist on an oath by children against tobacco and addictive drugs in all schools at the first school assembly. (b) Mass petition signed by over 100,000 school children of Kerala to the BCCI (1998) asking them to withdraw from ITC sponsorship of Cricket. (c) Mass petition signed by over 950,000 children to the Prime Minister of India, requesting tougher tobacco legislation (Yr. 2000) (d) Publications of popular booklets Ifs and Butts of Smoking, Answers to 50 questions on smoking. 2. Public Health Education We have prepared and distributed health education pamphlets on the following themes. (i)Diabetes (ii) Diabetes and BP (iii) Diabetes and Eyes (iv) Diabetes and Foot (v) Heart Attack 3. Public Health Surveys We have screened over 10,000 adult subjects for estimating the prevalence of diabetes, hypertension, obesity and hypercholesterolemia to estimate the burden of these disorders in Kerala population. The information is shared with the government. 4. Health Research HAP is the leading NGO in public health research in Kerala. We have the following notable contributions in this regard. (a) PROLIFE (Population Registry of Lifestyle Diseases) this is Indias first rural cohort assembled for studies into the future. The population exceeds 170, 000 and is under continuous surveillance since 2002. (b) PURE (Prospective Urban Rural Epidemiology) We are one of the 5 Indian partners of this global study pioneered by Mc Master University, Canada. (c) Study of Injuries- This study is carried out in PROLIFE population and is a collaboration between the department of Clinical Epidemiology, Mc Master University, Canada and HAP. (d) INDADE (Indo Danish Collaboration on Diabetes Epidemiology) this is a prospective study on the epidemiology of diabetes on a dynamic population of adults numbering over 8,000. The collaborators are University of Odense, Denmark, Novo Nordisk, Denmark and HAP 5. Saantwanam A unique employment generation activity for women of weaker sections utilizing the potential for health screening. Over 150 women from BPL houses are part of Saantwanam movement, were trained women traveling in scooters and equipped with measuring equipments, screen people at their door step for diabetes, hypertension, obesity and hypercholesterolemia. The charges levied are modest and many girls have net earnings of over 10,000 Rupees per month. About 700, 000 people are already been screened and tens of thousands are already detected with diabetes, hypertension, over weight etc.

Name: Tarun Pragati Club
Major_Activities1: The Organization came into existence on 11-07-1969 during the holy Birth Centenary year of Father of the Nation,Mahatma Gandhi and since then is working in the field of Art & Culture; Sports & Games; Library & Reading room; Welfare activities for Youth, Children, Women & the Aged and other socio-welfare activities as furnished below. 1)LIBRARY & READING ROOM ACTIVITIES: The Organization has a well-equipped Library having more than 3000 books and a no of newspapers & magazines and is functioning in a 440 sq.ft. hall of its own. Reading facilities are open to all. 2)SPORTS & GAMES ACITIVITIES: Various indoor and outdoor games are played daily in the club and Annual Sports Competition is held every year in which Block/District level competitors participate. 3)ART & CULTURAL ACTIVITIES: Ganesh Puja, Saraswati Puja, Independence Day, Republic Day etc are celebrated with ceremony and cultural programs are arranged on festive occasions. Odia dramma is staged every year by the members in association with local artists. Besides Drawing & Painting and Song competitions are conducted among school students on account of National Days and Special Occasions. 4)ACTIVITIES FOR CHILDREN: Balwadi with Nutrition Program from the year 1977-78 to 1986-87 and Early Childhood Education Program from 1983-84 to 2000-01 for 25 children of age group 06 years in each were effectively conducted. Rajiv Gandhi National Creche scheme for the children of said age group is now being implemented since 1987-88.Holiday Home camps for children of age group 9-16 were successfully conducted in the year 1975,1977,1979 and 1981 at Bhubaneswar, Puri and GopalpuronSea for a period of 15 days each. 5)ACTIVITIES FOR WOMEN & ADULTS: One year vocational training in tailoring & cutting for 25 rural adult women in 1982-83, one Readymade Garments unit for rural women in 1985-87,one Orientation Training Program for rural women in 1985 and Awareness Generation Program for rural women in 2013 were effectively conducted. Besides, one Adults Literacy Program was launched for adult/aged people for one year in 1978-79. 6)YOUTH ACITIVITIES: Most of the activities of the institution are cared by the young members. They are facilitated to attend various youth camps conducted by Nehru Yuva Kendra, Ministry of HRD and Central/State Social Welfare Board. Excursion Trips are arranged to visit places of importance inside and outside the state. 7)SOCIO-WELFARE & ECONOMIC ACTIVITIES: The Organization undertakes Pisciculture and agricultural activities to raise funds for the institution. The members have constructed two buildings for the organization bending their energy. They take initiative to aware the women of their legal rights and motivate them to form SHG groups. Besides Health & Sanitation activities and other welfare works are also taken up by the organization.

Name: KHAMIR Kachchh Heritage Art Music Information and Resources
Major_Activities1: About KHAMIR Khamir is a non-profit working with traditional artisan communities of Kachchh since its inception post-earthquake 2001. The organization was established by Nehru Foundation for Development (NFD) and Kutch Nav Nirman Abhiyan (KNNA) with a goal to revive and reposition the traditional crafts and creative industries through empowerment of tradition artisans of Kutch. 1. Sectoral interventions 1.1 GI for Kutch shawls: KHAMIR played key role in registration of Kutch shawl under the Geographical indications act. The 350 weavers of Kutch have organized themselves under the banner of a community based organization ‘Kutch Weavers Association (KWA)’ to receive GI tag. 1.2 Water security for block printers: Looking at the issues of water quality and quantity in the block printing crafts, KHAMIR initiated a study of the overall water security of two key block print clusters. The interventions has been planned after intervention. 1.3 Credit support: KHAMIR initiated a research study with copper bell artisans to understand their livelihood related issues. Khamir initiated its credit and social security programmes. Under credit program, the artisans were linked with Pahal Micro-finance to avail short term micro loans. 1.4 Health and education initiatives: The health is a crucial issues with vulnerable artisan groups like lacquer artisans. Organization is working with them on hands on basis to provide quality services during their and health issues and emergencies. 1.5 Technological interventions: The copper coated bell craft of Kutch requires different technological attentions due to issues associated with it. The problems of occupations hazards, lead content into the bells, the design of kiln etc. have been studied. 1.6 Craft workshops and craft education: KHAMIR is conducting craft workshops to spread knowledge and skill of crafts among students, visitors, young designers and general masses. The workshops provide hands on experience to the craft practices while spreading awareness about the same. 2. General interventions across the crafts 2.1 Design interventions: The design interventions of KHAMIR are in the areas of textile and hard material crafts. The extensive interventions were carried out in the crafts like leather, lacquer, copper bell and pottery with an aim to diversify the current product ranges. 2.2 Value chain innovations in crafts: The initiative was started with recycling the plastic waste through weaving skills which was followed by interventions in the areas of Kala cotton. The Kala cotton is an indigenous variety of cotton which Khamir started converting into yarn. The yarn is given to weavers to weaving. The third initiative in this row is camel wool value chain, where Khamir is trying to create a range of beautiful products out of wool of Kachchhi camels. 2.3 Curated exhibitions: The first exhibition “Textile legacies of Kachchh and Sindh” was organized in year 2011-12. The textiles created by artisans of Kachchh and Sindh have been displayed with authentic information. Khamir organized a second exhibition on the theme of “Bandhani of Kachchh: Ties across times” in year 2012-13. Khamir is planning to hold an exhibition on block print and batik print crafts in year 2013-14.
